name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 15 June 2017.

name: Le Président. –
text: Dear colleagues, I would like to start this session of parliamentary work with a thought full of emotion and gratitude for Simone Veil, a great figure of our time who has marked the history of Europe and who has made a fundamental contribution to development. of our Parliament. Simone Veil belongs to this generation of great minds, of which Helmut Kohl, who passed away a few days ago, was also a part. The first President of this Parliament elected by direct universal suffrage, Simone Veil accompanied the young Parliament in its first steps, steered it in the right direction and laid the foundations for its future development. She always wanted a political Parliament. This is what she said during her first speech as President: "The voice of our Assembly, strong in its legitimacy, will carry in all instances of the Community, and in particular at the highest level of political decision-making." Great is our debt to this great woman, whose memory will be honored tomorrow in this same hemicycle. I ask you to join me for a minute of silence in his memory.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I want to remind all my colleagues that the German Bundestag took an absolutely historic decision last Friday. Finally, Germany joined those EU Member States which have open marriage for same-sex couples. This is a historic moment, and as a German citizen and a member of the LGBTI community, I want to thank every single Member of this Parliament who has fought in recent years to make this possible. Were it not a Member State of the European Union, Germany probably would not be at that this stage right now. So thank you very much – for equality and for diversity. Love is unstoppable! (Applause)

name: Franck Proust
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, allow me, in my turn, and very briefly, at this opening of the plenary session, here in Strasbourg, in this Parliament which makes the heart of European democracy beat faster, to pay tribute, as you do. on behalf of the French delegation of the PPE Group, which I am chairing, spoke to Mrs Simone Veil, a French stateswoman, deeply European, who passed away last week. His soul will remain etched forever in our hearts and memories, and his work should guide our actions. Locked up in the death camps in Auschwitz in 1944 at the age of 16, a survivor of the atrocities of the Holocaust, Simone Veil embodies courage and symbolizes hope. Her destiny led her to overcome ideology and political divisions, defending, relentlessly and against conservatism, women's rights. Driven by freedom, Simone Veil has never given up in the face of sometimes the most cruel obstacles. Woman of peace, because victim of the tragedy of war, Ms. Veil worked with a unique tenacity for a political Europe bringing together peoples in their diversity. Let us be proud to walk through the door of this institution, which she chaired between 1979 and 1982, every day. Let us above all live up to what Mrs. Simone Veil undertook during a lifetime. The terrible conflicts that persist in parts of the world remind us of the inestimable value of peace. This peace on our continent, we owe it to great women and great men. Simone Veil will be part of it, forever. His talent and his political will to build Europe oblige us. Our societies are losing landmarks and symbols in the face of the immediacy of information and knowledge. But, if the words pass, the acts remain. Ms. Veil has, throughout a career in the service of citizens, ally the force of words to make change a reality. Tomorrow you said, Mr. President, an official tribute will be paid by this Assembly to Mrs Veil;but I wished, from the start of our proceedings, to salute the journey of this great lady: with an emotion, I confess, that I did not think I would ever be able to feel on the benches of this hemicycle.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe, I would like to associate myself both with your remarks and with the official ceremony which will be held in memory of this great and luminous a woman that Simone Veil was, to the words of my French colleagues, but also of all the Europeans who, through her disappearance, salute a symbolic woman of the 20th century. Beyond the most appalling torments that this century has caused with the Shoah, through her luminous personality as well as what she represents for the twentieth century, Simone Veil was both a politician and also a woman. quite simply, who knew how to combine her values, her demands, her will, her determination with a marked and strong character, and who was the first woman President of our European Parliament. She brought to my country values ​​that were passed on beyond France, which are those of human rights and women's rights through the texts that she supported. I am happy that in the heart of the European Parliament a tribute is paid to this luminous woman, both on the part of all European citizens, but obviously also of the French and members of my parliamentary group, to which she belonged.

name: Christine Revault D’Allonnes Bonnefoy
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group.- Mr President, thank you for this tribute.I agree with what my colleagues, Mr Proust and Mrs Griesbeck have said.I would like to say that Simone Veil, beyond her political career, was able to bring people together and did a great deal for Europe and for knowledge of Europe in France.She has also done a lot for women's rights.I am thinking in particular of the issue of abortion, which is authorized and legal.It was a fight at an extremely hard time, a fight for which we, the Socialists and Democrats, continue to honor his memory by ensuring that this fight is not in vain, is not over and can benefit allEuropeans.We therefore salute his memory.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- Mr President, I would also like, on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group, to thank you and our colleagues for the tribute you paid to Mrs Veil.She was a very important woman for women's rights on this continent, especially in France, but she was also a symbol for other countries.So I want to pay tribute to her for what she has done for women and also for Europe.

name: Presidente. –
text: I remind you that there will be an official celebration in this House tomorrow.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a very few minutes to tell this House, which many times have shown solidarity and attentive to the difficulties that some Member States are experiencing on the issue of immigration, what the situation we are experiencing is. Last week, 12,000 people arrived in Italy in two days. In the following days, in just one day, 5,000 more people. This is the rhythm of arrival. Now, we have chosen the path of welcome, but we are at a point of great difficulty. We therefore ask all colleagues, their countries and their governments and the Council that Europe's voice truly be expressed, in terms of solidarity and unity, for a country like mine that continues on the path of solidarity, of welcome, of the salvation of human lives, but is in a situation of great discomfort and difficulty. I think this is a voice, like that of Greece, which cannot remain unheard, in a Parliament like this which truly represents the will of the peoples in the name of that solidarity that makes us European. We talked about Simon Veil, those values, that project. This is one of the situations in which that project is put to the test: will it resist or will it be crushed instead?

name: Presidente. –
text: This House will have the opportunity to discuss it at the presentation of the Estonian Presidency's program.I have already spoken to Prime Minister Ratas, who assured me that the immigration issue is a European issue, as has always been emphasized by this Parliament.

name: Presidente. –
text: The final draft agenda, set by the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules, was distributed at the meeting of Thursday 29 June 2017. Due to the fact that on Wednesday morning President Juncker, President Tusk and myself will attend Simone Veil's funeral in Paris and therefore we will not be able to be present in the Chamber for the discussion on the conclusions of the European Council, after consultations with the political groups I wish to submit to the Chamber the following proposals to modify the final draft agenda. I propose a "Tribute to Simone Veil" item on Tuesday before the voting. On Wednesday the first item on the agenda should be changed as follows: "Council and Commission statements on preparation for the G20 summit" and voting would start at 12.00. Are there any objections? The agenda was thus amended. Monday: I have also received the following requests. The Europe of Nations and Freedom Group has called for statements by the Council and the Commission on "Frontex: alarming migration crisis off the Mediterranean coast of Spain" to be added as the first item on the agenda.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last Friday I visited in Warsaw the brand new headquarters of Frontex, the famous European border and coast guard agency, which is supposed to protect us from the massive and uncontrolled influx of illegal immigrants. After acknowledging that the overwhelming majority of these illegal immigrants cannot be considered refugees, Frontex officials alerted us to the very worrying situation off the Spanish coast. Indeed, the smuggling of people there is dramatically increasing and increased considerably, with more than 1,000 individuals intercepted per week. Unheard of in this area! These people come mainly from Morocco, which, on the one hand, has to deal with riots in the Rif and, on the other hand, has been for almost two years in full legal conflict with the European Union because of of a surprising ruling to say the least delivered by the European Court of Justice. That is why I believe that it is urgent that we have a debate on this very worrying situation ... (The President cut off the speaker) That is why I believe that it is urgent that we have a debate on this very worrying situation in off Spain, without forgetting of course the other entry points, in particular from Libya to Italy, where the collusion between NGOs and the smuggling mafias is more evident every day.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- I would ask you to add a debate on Norwegian whaling to the agenda, which will conclude with a resolution in September.Whales are among the most imposing animal species, but also among the most endangered species.That's why commercial whaling has been banned since 1986.Norway is one of the few countries to ignore this ban and since 1993 Norway has killed nearly 12,000 whales.That's more than Japan and Iceland combined!This year, Norway has increased the quota to nearly 1,000 whales.Dear colleagues, we must not let this happen.Whales are currently being hunted by Norway and I ask for your support to protect these animals.Because, as the European Parliament, are we watching the last whales being hunted down and in danger of extinction, or are we doing whatever we can to prevent this?I choose the latter and I hope you do too.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: - Mister President!We are very much in favor of the debate.Whaling is a critical issue and that is why the EPP is asking for a split vote.We are in favor of the debate, but we are not in favor of a resolution being passed here.

text: Mr Hazekamp, are you in favor of splitting your proposal, that is to have a vote on the debate first and then a vote on the resolution?Or he wants to keep his proposal intact by rejecting the request of the Hon.Rübig?

text: - This is a dilemma.A debate without a resolution doesn't say much in this case.Norway knows that there is an international ban and it is time for this Parliament to speak out clearly against international commercial whaling, including by Norway.That is why a debate alone is a good signal, but not enough, absolutely not!

name: Președintele. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Sorin Moisa, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on macro-financial assistance to the Republic of Moldova (COM (2017) 0014 - C8-0016/ 2017 - 2017/0007 (COD)) (A8-0185 / 2017).

name: Sorin Moisă
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the Republic of Moldova is in the process of recovering its economic stability after several very harsh years. Due to various circumstances – some domestic and self—inflicted, such as the well-known bank fraud, which has also led to an interruption of external support, and some external, such as a sharp decrease in exports to Russia and Ukraine – Moldova faces an external balance of payments crisis and has asked for assistance from international donors, notably the IMF and the EU.  In November last year, the IMF approved the three—year programme in the amount of almost USD 180 million and this programme is now well on track. The IMF has also calculated the country’s residual external financial needs for 2016—2018 at approximately EUR 400 million. The EU has also resumed its budgetary support operations, following the interruption in the context of the bank fraud, through the European Neighbourhood Instrument.  In January 2017, the Commission proposed the instrument that we are discussing today, a macro—financial assistance package covering approximately 25% – so only a quarter – of the country’s financial needs as identified by the IMF. This is in order to address the short-term balance of payments and fiscal vulnerabilities of the Moldovan economy. The proposed assistance therefore amounts to EUR 100 million; EUR 60 million would be a loan and EUR 40 million would be a grant to be disbursed in three instalments in 2017 – ideally – and in 2018. The Commission had proposed in its original draft text that strong conditionalities be attached to the assistance. These conditionalities have been thoroughly discussed in the two committees giving opinions in this House, the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Budgets, and of course in the Committee on International Trade. The result has been even stronger conditionalities attached to the disbursement of each of the three instalments. The principle is: no reforms, no money. It is the first time that the EU has taken such a tough stance, as the practice of the EU until now has been to grant the first instalment immediately and only attach some conditions to the subsequent ones.  The ambitious programme of reforms will cover financial sector governance, public sector governance, the fight against corruption, the fight against money laundering, energy sector reforms, and improvement of the business and investment climate. Parliament’s amendments have put strong emphasis on the independence of the judiciary, freedom and pluralism of the media, the depoliticisation of public administration, and the need to fight corruption and money laundering and to support the implementation of the DCFTA. We have clarified that conditions are to be attached to the disbursement of each and every one of the three instalments, that benchmarks should be clear as required by the European Court of Auditors, and that the assistance shall be immediately suspended or terminated if the conditions are not met.  If done properly, it is my strong belief that these reforms have a high potential systemic impact. These are reforms that will discipline and constrain the exercise of power by the government and any other economic or political actor for generations to come. The other two institutions have accepted one hundred percent of our requests. The agreement reached during the trilogue also includes a joint statement by Parliament, the Council and the Commission recalling that the necessary precondition for the disbursement of the assistance is respect for effective democratic institutions.  I have come up with this proposal to adopt this joint statement in order to address the concerns of colleagues in this House regarding the recent initiative by the authorities to change the electoral system in the Republic of Moldova. The process is still ongoing and the Venice Commission has recently made public its opinion on this process.  It is key that the Moldovan authorities duly take into account this recommendation. The joint statement puts a strong emphasis on the fact that the consideration by the Moldovan authorities of the recommendations of the Venice Commission will be part of the regular monitoring of the respect for the aforementioned precondition. The regular monitoring of this precondition is in fact a mandate that we have created and are giving to the Commission. I would encourage the Commission today to reconfirm the strength of its commitment in the context of this instrument that we have created together. This is important and is the underpinning factor for the consensus we have achieved in the House.  To conclude, in its current form, the decision gives us the green light – if we vote positively tomorrow – for the aid to Moldova. However, it does not mean immediate disbursement. If the decision is positive, the first instalment of the disbursement will reach Moldova in December. The European Union is therefore equipped with the right set of instruments to react to any potential developments in the Republic of Moldova.  I will conclude by thanking the shadows Mr Winkler from the PPE, Mr Takkula from ALDE, Mr Zahradil from the ECR, Mr Scholz from GUE and Ms Hautala from the Greens, as well as Mr Auštrevičius and Mr Mureşan, the rapporteurs for the opinion from the two opinion committees, and also Mr Preda from the PPE Group, who has played a key role in building a consensus in this House.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first thank the rapporteur, Mr Sorin Moisă and the Committee on International Trade for their valuable work, and also the Committee on Foreign Affairs and Committee on Budgets for their support. As you know, the European Commission submitted its proposal for a macro-financial assistance operation to Moldova in the context of difficult political and economic transition. Following the banking fraud scandal of 2014 the new Moldovan Government was appointed in February 2016, adopting a package of key reforms in areas like public governance and anti-corruption. In support of this new reformed path, the EU and Moldova agreed on the roadmap for priority reforms at the beginning of 2016 and with the Foreign Affairs Council conclusions of 16 February 2016. Moldova, which is one of the poorest countries in the European neighbourhood needs macro-financial assistance to cover its external financing needs and underpin its slow recovery from the recession in 2015. This macro-financial assistance complements the assistance of the International Monetary Fund, which resumed its assistance and approved a new, extended fund facility agreement on 7 November last year. Therefore, it is crucial that the EU, together with other international donors, uses this window of opportunity for reforms in Moldova and supports the new Moldovan Government in its efforts to implement key reforms and bring back economic recovery. However, the Commission shares the concerns of Parliament with regard to important areas like corruption, money laundering, independent judiciary, independent media, and the implementation of the EU-Moldova Association Agreement. Therefore, the Commission supports the five amendments to the recitals of its proposals to address these concerns. Let me also reassure you that the Commission will entirely be guided by these new recitals when implementing this assistance and, in particular, when designing the conditionality of this operation of the memorandum of understanding between the EU and Moldova. The Commission also shares the concerns of Parliament regarding the recent initiatives in Moldova to introduce a new electoral system. Therefore we support the joint statement of the three institutions, recalling that the precondition for granting macro-financial assistance is that the beneficiary country respects effective democratic mechanisms, including a multi-party parliamentary system and the rule of law, and guarantees respect for human rights. The Commission and the European External Action Service will closely monitor the fulfilment of this pre-condition throughout the lifecycle of this operation and will pay utmost attention to how Moldova follows up on the recommendations of international partners, in particular the recommendations of the Venice Commission and of the Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe related to the proposed changes in the electoral system. Before closing my remarks I would like to underline again that no disbursement of macro-financial assistance for Moldova will take place if the political preconditions as well as specific economic and financial conditions are not fulfilled. I hope we can count on Parliament’s support for Moldova on its path to reform and I would like to underline that the Council, in a letter of 15 June this year, from COREPER, confirmed the approval of the Commission’s proposal as agreed in the trilogue, subject the approval of the European Parliament.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. –Mr President, Moldova’s future depends on much more than yet another financial tranche. Plans to change the election system are received with such great caution in both Brussels and Strasbourg, and rightly so. Even more importantly, in Moldova the opposition parties and civil society at large are alarmed and protesting. Everyone is asking for a fair European debate and a consensus—based decision and we do not see this happening. Instead we read today about yet another political party leaving the consultations on election law. I wish to draw the attention of this House to the joint statement of all EU institutions that the Commissioner has just mentioned, which is an integral part of the decision and which makes very clear reference to the Venice Commission recommendations. It is crucial to ensure that these recommendations are fully respected. We must also make sure that we are sending the right message to the Moldovan people, as there is a high risk of manipulation and political misinterpretation. Moldova does indeed have certain privileges, but it has very serious duties. I do hope that everyone in Moldova understands this and I wish for great cooperation with Moldova when it comes to all the issues in front of us.

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: draftsman of the opinion Committee on Budgets. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen, my aim as rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets has been to make sure that the Republic of Moldova meets the conditions for receiving these European funds and that we create the conditions, the premises for the money to get there. where they are most needed, namely, in humans. What criteria do I mean? First of all, on the preconditions for the existence of the rule of law and a multiparty system, and in this area, Mr Dombrovskis, I urge you to take all necessary action with the Chisinau authorities to ensure that we that the electoral system fully complies with the recommendations of the Venice Commission so that this money can reach the citizens only in these conditions and, only if the recommendations of the Venice Commission are fully implemented, the money can reach the people. Secondly, I am referring to the conditions relating to the fight against corruption, the fight against money laundering, which the rapporteur mentioned and which I introduced in the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Here, Mr Vice-President, the role of the European Commission is very clear: to monitor the situation closely and to pay each installment only if these specific conditions are met. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 149 (8)))

name: Președintele. –
text: Mr Lucke picked up a blue card - too late for the first speaker, Mr Auštrevičius, and too early for the next speaker, Mr Mureșan.So, as such, you can't, because you had to do this while Mr. Auštrevičius was speaking.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: - Mister President!I reported to Mr Mureşan with the blue card when Mr Mureşan started to speak, just as is usual.I did not want to ask Mr Auštrevičius a question, I would like to ask Mr Mureşan a question.I got in touch during his verbal contribution - namely at the very beginning of his verbal contribution.I ask you to take this into account, as is always the case.

name: President. –
text: It means that you knew in advance what Mr Mureşan would say, and therefore that would provoke your blue card. Is this the understanding? Let me tell you that you have a very good sense of premonition.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it is not your obligation to judge what I knew or did not know. I want to pose a question please.

name: President. –
text: That is all right. You may ask your question.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Mureşan, you spoke very politically.I would like to ask you a question about Moldova's ability to repay its debt.Is there a debt sustainability analysis for Moldova?Who did this debt sustainability analysis?What is the result of this debt sustainability analysis?

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – The position of the European Union has been constant throughout recent years and we have always said that if the International Monetary Fund comes to the conclusion that the Republic of Moldova’s debt is sustainable, the economy is strong enough and the conditions of an agreement with the IMF are met, then the European Union stands ready also to help the Republic of Moldova.  In November last year, the IMF came to a positive conclusion and decided to proceed to give credit to the Republic of Moldova. Given these circumstances, I am of the opinion that, economically, the Republic of Moldova is in a condition to receive this financing and to return it. However, all of the other political conditionalities mentioned by Commissioner Dombrovskis and I remain important to make sure that the money reaches its objective.

name: Daniel Caspary
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! For us in the Group of the European People's Party, the people of Moldova are at the center. We all know that the situation in Moldova is very borderline for many, many people and that Moldova is one of the poorest countries in Europe. Nevertheless, it is important to us that certain conditions are complied with. That is why I am very, very grateful to the Commission for once again pointing out many conditions that are very close to our hearts, namely the question of the rule of law and democracy in Moldova, the question of combating corruption, the question of how to deal responsibly with people Money that we, as Parliament, will hopefully be able to make available tomorrow. But what the government seems to be up to now on the issue of suffrage is intolerable. That is why it is very good that the institutions have agreed on the joint declaration, in which we all again explicitly refer to the conditions of the Venice Commission. But I definitely hope, Commissioner, that the Commission will really make it clear once again that this electoral law cannot be changed as the government in Moldova seems to envisage, but that we can only release the money if the terms of the Venice Commission are really implemented one-to-one. And I would be very, very grateful if the Commission would make this clear either in your closing statement, Commissioner, or tomorrow before the vote. You will see that this topic has been addressed in every speech so far. We must not allow the democratic situation in Moldova to deteriorate and then still pay money to reward it. With this in mind, I would also like to thank our colleague Iuliu Winkler, who was in charge of this dossier for our group. We would we would be delighted if, tomorrow, when we made the money available, we really agreed on what our conditions are, and if the Commission then really ensures, without a back door, that these conditions are met.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – As you know, the basic issue here is whether to let the Republic of Moldova go into the Eurasian Economic Union, cooperating with Russia, or to bring it closer to the European Union. This is ultimately what it is about. Do you not think that, if we don’t grant this macro-financial assistance, the people of the Republic of Moldova are going to be very disappointed vis-à-vis the position of the European Union, and that we have to do whatever we can in order to bring them to the West not to the East?

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear colleague!If I expressed myself unclearly or the translation was not entirely clear, then I thank you very much for the question.We all agree that we would like Moldova to develop in the direction of the European Union and in the direction of freedom, democracy and the rule of law.That is precisely why it is important to us, because we want a democratic Moldova based on the rule of law close by, and that is why we attach great importance to providing assistance - that is out of the question for us in the group.But we want to have ensured that the democratic situation in Moldova will continue to improve and not deteriorate in the coming months and years, and that's exactly where many - such as the Venice Commission or many politically active people in Moldova - unfortunately have worries at the moment.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! Dear Colleagues! For many years we have repeatedly transferred funds - including to Moldova - in the hope that reforms will come about, that conditions for the people there will improve. This has often not been the case in the past. It is a catastrophe, which partly took place there, in which all sorts of so-called democratic parties were involved - one of the prime ministers is therefore in jail, others are under indictment. That is why it is absolutely right that we say: We do not want to continue along this path. The result has not only been that we have felt more and more critical, the result has also been that the people of Moldova have turned more and more away, not only from their respective governments, but also from those who support them - namely us. That is why it is correct: this cannot be continued. Now we have a new government that has really not only talked about one thing or another, but also delivered it. The International Monetary Fund has confirmed this and acted accordingly positively. We expect it to continue so that not only is there talk, but delivery is made. That is why I say very clearly - so as not to allow any misunderstandings to arise: it is not our business which suffrage Moldova gives itself. That is out of the question at all! Because they are not under our patronage. It is up to you whether you adopt English or German or another option. But how they introduce it, with whom they discuss, whether they seek consensus, whether they involve the NGOs - that interests us so that we can come to a conclusion in the end. In any case, I am in favor of us saying a clear yes to macro-financing tomorrow under the conditions that have been mentioned here several times.

name: Hannu Takkula
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Sorin Moisă, for a good report. As he and many others have already pointed out in this debate, Moldova is currently facing many challenges, both economic and political. It is important to remember that the purpose of macro-financial assistance has never been to interfere in the political decisions of the recipient country, but purely to create economic stability around the EU in countries such as Moldova. Moldova has slowly emerged from the 2014 banking crisis, but remains the poorest country in Europe. Creating an economically sustainable base requires macro-financial assistance. As for the much-discussed reform of the electoral law, it is, as the Venice Commission said, a matter for the sovereign state, and the EU has no power to intervene in decisions concerning it. However, the EU's most economic and political work must be based on the EU's own values ​​of democracy, human rights and the rule of law. Therefore, I think it is reasonable to make these a condition for financial assistance as well. As an independent state, Moldova has the right to make its own political decisions, but the European Union must uphold its own values. For this reason, I am very satisfied with the agreement, which was set for negotiations with the Commission and the Council, and financing terms.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! With 100 million euros, the Moldovan government should be able to pay teachers in the autumn and service the debt rates at the IMF. As a group, we have always affirmed that macro-financial assistance should not be used to map out new debt prospects; instead of loans, grants should largely be granted. In the report it just submitted on the implementation of financial aid, the EU Commission assesses the economic and political situation in the country in 2016 as increasingly difficult. I therefore ask you, Commissioner: do the latest developments in Moldova, in your assessment, meet the characteristics of a reliable partner acting in accordance with the rule of law? The country's population continues to suffer from the influence of oligarch Vlad Plahotniuc on the government and the economy. You and we know that. With this in mind, I advocated strict preconditions for the payment of each tranche. This explicitly includes respect for human rights and basic democratic rights and an independent judiciary that is bound by the rule of law. In the past week we experienced the opposite - very specifically and precisely: Grigore Petrenco and seven other young people were asked on June 28 for the organization and participation in a demonstration on social justice according to one - unanimously classified by all international observers - dubious Sentenced to three to four and a half years in prison. The Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, the German and US governments describe the men as political prisoners. Should this be used to set the political course before the next elections? We just talked about the right to vote. Commissioner, I expect you to give a very specific assessment of this situation before the government receives any money is transferred.Because, as I quote: "Macro-financial aid presupposes respect for human rights and effective democratic mechanisms in the recipient country" - according to the Commission.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, there has been an agreement between the Council, the Commission and Parliament since 2013 on a certain model macrofinancial assistance and now, with the case of Moldova, I think that more and more we start to see that this instrument has to be more linked with the conditionalities on reforms of the judiciary and other aspects of rule of law, of democracy, respect for human rights and, as has been said by many speakers already, the situation in Moldova has not improved as we would expect from an associated partner country of the European Union.  Therefore I believe that this macrofinancial assistance is different from the other agreements that have been struck between the institution since 2013. We start to see that an instrument that takes the form of budget support needs to be based on trust that the money is going to where it is needed and, as the previous speaker, Mr Scholz, said, that we are not generating debts for the future. We are indeed generating debts for the future if the Commission and the External Action Service are not very consistent with the conditioning of this macrofinancial assistance with, for instance, a very strong fight against corruption, and against money laundering.  I must remind the House about the rather recent understanding of the role of Moldovan banks, and even of Moldovan judges, in some of the biggest money-laundering scandals in our environment. The so-called Russian Laundromat revealed a lot of the reality of the banking system and the judiciary in Moldova and we cannot let that go easily. Also we still remember the embezzlement by which one billion euro was transferred from three Moldovan banks to shell companies in Hong Kong and other offshore havens.  At the same time as we are fighting against money laundering, against tax evasion, we should also expect that our associated partner countries do their utmost to eradicate these kind of things from their system. So I also, on behalf of the Green/European Free Alliance Group, expect the Commission to implement and take seriously the joint declaration that the three institutions agreed when we concluded the negotiations, and I also want to hear how the Commission is going to follow the situation and implement this.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, we are here discussing the spending of EU funds, and money which rightfully belongs to the taxpayer, to be given to Moldova in what is known as macro-financial assistance. I see plenty of politics here, and plenty of expectations being placed on Moldova in return for the cash, but let us be honest here: Moldova ranks at a miserable 127th place in Transparency International’s measure of corruption, lower down than Pakistan and Communist Cuba. The explanatory statement that comes with this report says that the free trade agreement between the European Union and Moldova has contributed to the process of economic recovery. Well, that is what free trade does! If only the European Union actually focused on breaking down barriers to trade rather than creating them, perhaps it would be less of a negative force throughout the world. The Economic Freedom Index places Moldova worse than countries like Rwanda and Swaziland when it comes to being attractive to trade and investment. The solution, here again, is not to give Moldova more money: the solution is for Moldova to become more competitive. Is giving so much money to a country so notorious for official corruption and economic poor performance really a good use of taxpayers’ money? For all our fine words, this is in essence foreign aid being given by taxpayers, so, surely to goodness, it should meet a common-sense definition of what foreign aid is for.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has become the people's prison. It seems that the European Commission wants to do its business on the backs of nations. This is very damaging, because the European Union, ultimately, is no longer the body which guarantees peace in Europe, but instead becomes a conflicting actor. Today we see that the European Union wants to subdue the nations, and this macro-financial deal is unfortunately going in the wrong direction. In October 2017, Moldova was granted observer status with the Eurasian Economic Union. This has sparked the ire of the European Union, which sees it as a declaration of war. Yet nations have the right to decide with whom they want to cooperate. The Moldovan nation, unfortunately, has been very weakened culturally, because it is shared between East and West, but above all because this nation of 3.5 million inhabitants - that I had the opportunity to visit recently - is a nation left behind. Today you want to play on the sensitivity of this nation to attract it and bring glory to the European Union, but in fact you are only going to cause trouble with Russia once again. Neutrality is in my opinion the best status for Moldova. She must not take sides with either the European Union or Russia. I believe that Russia has shown that it is capable of temperance with regard to the will of the European Union. That is why today I urge you to respect the peoples, to respect the nations. Don't start a new war!

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, macro-financial assistance to Moldova, if not linked to the implementation of an ambitious economic and structural reform program, is doomed to failure and, therefore, I cannot consent to the provision of financial support. Moldova lags far behind the European average of countries that meet at least the Copenhagen criteria. It takes bold steps and a break with the bad communist past to improve areas such as economic and public governance, the fight against corruption and money laundering, the efficiency and independence of the judiciary and the governance of the judiciary. . I also have many reservations about the usefulness and efficiency of supporting the rapid implementation of the global and in-depth free trade area.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the Republic of Moldova needs macro-financial assistance, and when I say the Republic of Moldova, I am thinking of its citizens, not politicians. Unfortunately, Mr Dodon, chairman, and Plahotniuc, coordinator, did not understand this. Instead of supporting the reforms that citizens need, the two decided that the absolute priority today is a new electoral law, one that will ensure their eternal re-election. In fact, the deputy Sârbu, rapporteur of the Parliament for this law, a combination between a project of Dodon and a project of Plahotniuc, said very clearly: we intend to have only two parties. The Venice Commission explained the lack of opportunity for this electoral law and I am glad to see the statement of the European Commission, made by Commissioner Dombrovskis, who explained the conditions under which the money from this macro-financial assistance will be sent to Moldova. I will say more clearly what I said to the members of the Democratic Party who were invited by their colleagues in the Socialist Group in the European Parliament in Brussels: withdraw this draft electoral law. It has nothing to do with the emergencies of Moldovan society. No European citizen is willing to pay money for electoral experiments or for the power ambitions of Putin's friend Dodon and the friend of the European Socialists, Plahotniuc. Withdraw this project. Think of the interests of the citizens, not your perpetuation in power. This is, I think, the condition under which we must send the money to Chisinau.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Mr President, if the Republic of Moldova is on the agenda of our plenary session today it is because that country is, and remains, at the top of the Union’s agenda. And, let me be absolutely clear on this, Moldova on its European path has the full support and commitment of four political Groups across this Parliament. Macro-financial assistance is one of many tools at our disposal for accompanying and supporting the Republic of Moldova on its process of political association and economic integration with the European Union and, although some areas require additional efforts, overall there has been substantial progress since the start of the current Executive’s term of office. This week, after very thorough, comprehensive and attentive negotiations with the Council and the Commission based on a clear mandate, the House will vote on this macro-financial assistance. This support will not only be a sign of recognition of the renewed commitment by the Executive, it will also constitute an additional lever of motivation and pressure for the implementation of the much-needed reform agenda, in line with the Association Agreement, the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement and all the views colleagues in the House have expressed today. But first and foremost, EU macro-financial assistance will acknowledge the European aspirations and ambitions of the Moldovan people, and will also convey a strong signal of support and encouragement at this important and difficult time. I would like to underline the fact that the EU will be applying rigorous, clear and strict conditionality criteria, in line with Parliament’s position, and that this conditionality will be attached to the disbursement of each tranche, including the first one. As I have emphasised before, this Parliament has been most effective and successful when it has acted with full consensus in its approach vis-à-vis the Republic of Moldova. I would like to conclude by thanking the rapporteur, as well as and especially Mr Auštrevičius, Ms Harms and Ms Fotyga, for supporting Moldova at this crucial time.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, we have before us the debate on a tough memorandum imposed on Moldova. The conditions imposed by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund when intervening are well known. These matters of conditionality in practice mean political interference in the functioning of a state. Practically, we have seen in Greece what a memorandum is. Here, for Moldova, 100 million euros are supposed to be given; 60 as a loan and 40 as a grant. How much of this money will go to the state economy and how much will go to the citizens themselves? Or will lenders eventually be repaid? There is a huge bilingualism. He calls for the resolution - correctly - an independent judiciary. But Mr Dombrovskis, in Greece the troika and the Eurogroup are intervening to acquit three European Union technical experts involved in a lawsuit over the sale and re-lease scandal of 28 government properties. Mr Dombrovskis, by what right do you intervene in Greek Justice? There are your own statements of June 29, 2017 in which you link the granting of the last installment of the loan with the exemption of the specific experts. Is this an independent Justice? We are waiting for an answer, Mr Dombrovskis, on this issue. By what right do you intervene in Greek Justice? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, there is no doubt that the European Neighborhood Instrument, which supports this macro-financial assistance for the Republic of Moldova, is fully justified, as the Commission has stated, and this agreement is not, in fact, a gesture of extreme goodwill towards Moldova, but it is largely a loan that is conditioned by the fulfillment of certain criteria. The criteria proposed by the Commission and the Council are the right ones, they are in line with the European values ​​that we all need to protect. What, from my point of view, is not correct, is to introduce a new criterion, a new conditionality, which is related to the electoral law. Dear colleagues, the European Union must respect its own values ​​and these values ​​include the fact that it can never afford to intervene in elements of a state's sovereignty. The European Union cannot ask a member state for a certain type of electoral law. This is the sovereign will of that state, and I think that introducing an additional criterion from this point of view would mean falling into cheap populism and politics, which do no honor to this Parliament.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - It is not often that the European Commission makes financial assistance, which is of course partly linked to a loan, conditional on this assistance being subject to certain conditions. I think that is right in the case of Moldova. Especially because the situation in Moldova has not been rosy for several years, it is very dynamic, and demonstrations, riots two or three years ago, have shown that Moldova must embark on a new so-called democratic path and therefore decide where it wants to direct its the future, the future of generations to come. Some, of course, raise the dilemma here as to whether to turn to the East or the West and the European Union, and in the past attempts have been made, even in quotation marks, to contribute financially to the decision to make Moldova more open to the European Union. , also through association or trade agreements. However, something happened that was not good. That many funds have somehow disappeared and therefore have not achieved their goal for which they were given. And that is also why I think that it is really necessary in this part, in this package, to watch closely, so that this part of the fight against corruption, freedom of speech, in a way also support for democracy, is the one that will be achieved with these funds. I am therefore convinced that the Commission will also use its instruments to know and keep us informed of the progress of these most critical points, so that we can say that Moldova is on the right track also in terms of receiving financial assistance.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Dombrovskis! Some previous speakers have already said that the disbursement of macro-financial assistance must be linked to certain conditions, and these are the principles of the rule of law and democracy - the fight against corruption and money laundering and, of course, the implementation of the Venice guidelines. Commission on the right to vote. However, I would like to add a fourth point: the disbursement of the macro-financial aid and the resumption of disbursements from the European Neighborhood Instrument are linked to the fact that this banking fraud scandal, which has already been mentioned several times today, has also been completely cleared up. Because this is not just any crime, it is a crime of the century - as the international media call it. In fact, three banks managed to steal a billion euros - that's half of the National Bank's reserves, and that's 17 percent of Romania's gross domestic product. The majority shareholder in these three banks is the chairman of the Democratic Party, the party that is now the prime minister. It doesn't look good, and our Romanian colleagues know more about this than anyone else. Therefore, particular caution must be observed here, and special measures must be taken when the funds are disbursed so that everything is done correctly.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Moldova, after two difficult years, is in the process of recovering its political and economic stability. Starting in 2014, a serious banking scandal and a substantial contraction in agricultural production have led the country to economic recession. Last November, the International Monetary Fund approved a three-year extended credit service agreement for $ 179 million in favor of Moldova, with an implementation budget considered satisfactory. The European Union must resume its macro-financial assistance program towards Moldova, but the conditions of reliability of the country must also be carefully checked. Assistance must be conditional on the implementation of an ambitious program of economic and structural reforms: I am thinking in particular of the strengthening of governance in the financial sector, the fight against corruption and money laundering and the efforts to increase the independence of the judiciary , without forgetting the strategic importance of improving the energy sector, in particular by ensuring the independence of the national regulatory authority.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, since the riots of 2009, Moldova has seen a succession of pro-European majorities.The leaders of this policy - Vlad Filat, in prison for corruption, Vlad Plahotniuc, the main oligarch and main corruptor of the country, leader of the ruling party - have together, with their obligees, stolen a billion dollars from the Moldovan banking system.We have given, so to speak, a permit to steal to this mafia which proclaims itself for the European Union.And you still want to add 100 million euros?It’s a bit too much.Don't you think so?Also stop the game in Transnistria, where a border between Ukraine and Transnistria is being restored.Why are we trying to increase tensions?Do we want war again?My dear colleagues, to love democracy, to love choice, is to allow Moldova to always be in balance between East and West and to remain itself.

name: President. –
text: I can only see that there are good oligarchs and bad oligarchs.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!I would definitely like to stand up for support for Moldova.Of course, we cannot hide the truth - there are cases of corruption, there are things that should fundamentally change in Moldova - but this should not speak (as argued by MP Schaffhauser) in favor of withdrawing from the Eastern neighborhood policy, in favor of withdrawing from the policy of support for European and libertarianthe aspirations of the Moldovan society that wants to share the fate of free European nations.By withdrawing from this game, Putin is allowed to dominate that part of Europe.Therefore, let us follow the rules, let us not allow corruption to repeat itself, but patiently and systematically show our support to the Moldovan society, which wants to share the fate of free nations with us.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I will vote for this assistance to the Republic of Moldova.I want to emphasize that the people of the Republic of Moldova have suffered perhaps more than the people of any other country in transition - starting with the deportations to Siberia and ending with this transition, which seems to end in Moldova.I want to fully support the position of the European Commission presented by First Vice-President Dombrovskis: it is correct and right.We will approve this assistance agreement, and the release of the money to Moldova will be done exactly as the first vice-president stated very clearly, insofar as the established conditionalities are met.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, from the very beginning I have said that I will vote on this report and I will argue. I do not know how many of you have visited, and how many times, the Republic of Moldova. From 1990 until now, I go three or four times a year. There are things that have been in progress, there are many things that need to be changed, but for three who stole from the bank, we will not punish the citizens of the Republic of Moldova. The Republic of Moldova needs macro-financial assistance and the Commission has presented very well the economic and political conditionalities. The rapporteur, together with the shadow rapporteurs, has also prepared a voting report which will bring this extraordinarily important support to the Republic of Moldova. We cannot reject the provision of macro-financial support, because it would deprive the European Union of a useful tool for promoting reforms in the Republic of Moldova and would discourage the citizens of this state. In the global context, I believe that there is a need to increase citizens' trust in the European Union; and citizens of the Republic of Moldova. So I will vote on this report and congratulate the rapporteurs.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - President! The recipe we see this time in the case of Moldova is familiar. They do it regularly against former communist and socialist countries. The European Union and the International Monetary Fund, the IMF, are so-called 'quid pro quoja'. Give it, make democracy, do economic reforms, and we will give you money. What is meant by this? Economic reform in their language means privatizing everything that is national property. Our lands must be given to them, our agriculture must be allowed to be artificially destroyed, our markets must be opened up to products that are often of poor quality. Let's know this recipe! As a Hungarian, I am very proud that the IMF yoke has been shaken off our necks. How does the European Union teach us democracy now? By saying that we will accept mass migration to our country against our will. Thank you very much, we are not asking for this democracy. We are equal members of the European Union, so they are not giving us mercy. God is protecting the Moldovan people from what you and the IMF want to force on them.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me conclude by underlining the importance of this decision with a view to supporting key reforms in Moldova. As you know, any amendment beyond the five amendments to the report of the Committee on International Trade (INTA) would trigger a second reading and significantly delay the adoption process, as well as the disbursement of macro-financial assistance which is still foreseen this year, provided that conditions are met.  Therefore, we count on your political support for Moldova and hope that you will follow the INTA report and approve the Commission proposal as agreed in a trilogue of 6 of June of this year.

name: Sorin Moisă
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like first of all to thank the Commission for the very clear stance on the joint statement adopted by the three institutions and the intention stated here publicly, beyond doubt, to properly enforce it. I hope that is to the satisfaction of most colleagues, and I was happy to see that both Mr Preda and Mr Stolojan seemed to be satisfied with the Commission’s very clear position. I shall tackle very briefly some of the issues that were raised on this. The common thread of the discussion has been the alleged – probably real – excessive power of some business people or oligarchs in Moldova. I truly believe in the following reality: the package of conditionalities attached to this MFA has true transformative potential to limit any type of arbitrary exercise of power in the Republic of Moldova. We have focused so much on the electoral issue – which is important, that is why we have addressed it through the joint declaration – but I truly believe that the reforms will be there for a generation, maybe those attached to the package itself, and this is far more important than simply a discussion on electoral reform nowadays. I also believe that there is a false dichotomy between corruption and competitiveness. In order for a country to be competitive, it cannot be corrupt. It does need to address corruption, so I believe we are doing the right thing with the DCFT, on the one hand, and with properly addressing and incentivising the fight against corruption Moldova, that is indeed the right thing to do. I would also encourage the Moldovan authorities to truly reach out to the opposition and to civil society, and engage in this discussion if the discussion continues on the transformation of the electoral system, but I also encourage the other parties to accept the invitation for dialogue. A proper democracy requires loyal democrats on all sides. And there is a bit of a paradox here: if you try to impose consensus from the outside, then a party walking out of that consensus could have a sort of veto power which may be seen as unfair. All of that said, I believe we have, if not a consensus, then we are close to a significant majority here ourselves and I hope that this will be confirmed by a positive vote tomorrow. Thank you again to all of you who have contributed to building this consensus in the House.

name: Președinte. –
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, 4 July 2017. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Commission has proposed providing macro-financial assistant (MFA) to Moldova of up to EUR 100 million. The implementation of the MFA would go hand-in hand with the budgetary support operations financed by the European Neighbourhood Instrument that have been frozen since early 2015.  Moldova has faced a difficult period over the last two years both economically and politically. While the PPE supported the Commission proposal to a large extent, it introduced a stronger conditionality for granting macro-financial assistance to contribute to a greater political and macroeconomic stability of the country. These conditions include the strengthening of economic and financial governance, including a thorough, result-oriented investigation into bank fraud, good energy governance, an accountable, transparent and merit-based civil service, the freedom, independence and pluralism of the media, sustainable development and poverty reduction and the political independence of the judiciary.  A pre-condition for granting the MFA and for the disbursement of each of the three instalments should be that Moldova respects effective democratic mechanisms – including a multi-party parliamentary system – and the rule of law, and guarantees respect for human rights.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The Republic of Moldova urgently needs financial support, and the European Union's decision to provide aid of 100 million euros is a strong signal of solidarity with this country and its citizens. There is a close relationship between Romania and Moldova, uniting our language and a common past, and our country wants Moldova to be part of the European family. Therefore, Romania supports the decision to provide macro-financial assistance to the Republic of Moldova, considering that the pro-European evolution of the neighbors across the Prut can be achieved only through concrete measures. Beyond the economic aspects, this decision must be understood as a proof of the EU's commitment to support the Republic of Moldova in implementing structural reforms. At the same time, in the context of the Union's long-term geostrategic objectives, support for Moldova is becoming essential to ensure a stable political climate at its borders. However, macro-financial assistance is not a gift, it is accompanied by very strict conditions. The political and economic conditionalities set out in the decision and the memorandum of understanding provide the Union with a solid tool for monitoring the reform process in this state, and Moldova will have to fulfill these conditions before the release of each tranche of assistance.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Marlene Mizzi, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on European standards - the implementation of Regulation (EU) No 182/2011.1025/2012 (2016/2274 (INI)) (A8-0213 / 2017).

name: Marlene Mizzi
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, although we may not realise it, standards are everywhere around us – in healthcare, food, transportation, construction, cosmetics, energy and so many other things. In each sector, standards are a necessary component and a mechanism that can improve health and safety for our citizens, can protect consumers and raise their confidence, guarantee safe products and services, reduce costs and enhance performance for businesses, increase sales and the take-up of new technologies, boost competitiveness and innovation in Europe. However, it is important that standards are developed in an open, inclusive and transparent system, based on close partnership, cooperation and broad support of industry, public authorities, consumers, workers and citizens, i.e. all the stakeholders. This is of paramount importance when standards are developed for products and services that can affect the health and safety and the wellbeing of people. And this is the main thrust of my report, Standards for the 21st Century. The objective of this report is to contribute to the ongoing debate and to set the European Parliament’s priorities in response to the Commission standardisation package, including the joint initiative on standardisation and development of ICT standards. The report will also contribute to the first interinstitutional dialogue and to the Commission’s Annual Work Programme 2018, which will be adopted in July. I would like to express my gratitude to the shadows and to the Commission for their open and collaborative work on this report. In fact, the Commission has decided to postpone their Annual Work Programme by one month, so that they can take on board our recommendations, which will be voted upon tomorrow. The standardisation environment is changing and is challenging. To respond to these challenges, I based the report on a number of salient points that are essential for the future of the European standardisation system. First, the report acknowledges that there is more to the standardisation process than an economic aspect. The European standardisation system must be based on an inclusive, holistic and common approach whereby SMEs, consumer and citizen goals – particularly those related to economic, social and health issues and the environment – are fully integrated into the standardisation process. Second, the report stresses the importance and success of the Standardisation Regulation 1025. The European system is unique, but we should always strive to improve it, without undermining all the positive work which has been done. There are two different ecosystems at European level for the development of EU standards, and that is CEN/CENELEC and ETSI. Both systems have their existing good practices but they need to be explored further. That is why the report makes some valuable suggestions on how to further improve, support and strengthen the work of the European standardisation organisations, by safeguarding that the development of standards remains open, transparent and guided by European interests. Third, it is important to stress that standards are not a legislative tool, and they should not be used as such. They are a voluntary, market-driven tool, providing technical requirements and guidance for the implementation of EU legislation. Fourth, standards is an extremely competitive area at international level and in order to maintain Europe’s leadership position in technical development and global trade, we need to pay more attention to the global role and relevance of standards. Fifth, developing standards is a long-term investment and not everyone can afford the time, expertise and investment in this complex process. Therefore, a key point in the report is supporting SMEs’ participation in the process of developing standards. The report also recognises the key role of ICT standards for the future development of the digital single market, FRAND – fair, reasonable and non-discriminatory – royalty-free licensing and open-source software implementation. Having open standardisation processes based on FRAND licensing terms, which address the legitimate interests of both the holders of rights and potential licensees, is now more important than ever. Finally, we need to increase the awareness and knowledge about standards and to explain how standardisation works and when it can be used. We are therefore proposing an Annual Standardisation Forum where once a year stakeholders can meet to discuss European standards. So I hope that you can support this report at tomorrow’s vote so that this institution can send a strong message about the importance of the European standardisation system.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. - Mister President! First of all, thank you very much, Ms. Mizzi, for your excellent work and for taking on board the suggestions made by the ITRE committee. As someone who has spent his entire professional life in this industry, I know that it is important that we need standards in information and communication technology in order to truly achieve the digital single market. But in this discussion - not with you, but with a few other colleagues - I have repeatedly noticed that we still have some catching up to do here, including on the subject of prejudice. I noticed that American companies are often demonized on this subject. We should stop, because we also need cooperation with the Americans, especially when it comes to this issue of information and communication technology. Second, we should stop demonizing big companies. Of course, it is important that we support small and medium-sized companies. But why are corporations something bad? Because we all know that corporations - including the big ones - need many thousands of small and medium-sized companies and vice versa. Thirdly, I would like to point out that standards should not be confused with harmonization. We need the standards to create competition, because competition between small units always leads to a stronger whole. But if we now harmonize in Europe at the same time - and we do this at every opportunity - then we will disrupt and destroy competition. It's like running a marathon: of course you have to know that you can run 42 kilometers and 195 meters, and that applies to everyone. But imagine if the runners made a promise at the beginning of the run that they would all finish at the same time arrive.Then competition and with it the European internal market would be destroyed.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I want to thank Ms Mizzi for her report on European standardisation. This is an important document; important for us, important for the European standardisation community. It sets out a balanced view on several questions on the European standardisation system and as I can see from it, we agree on the fundamental principles in the area. Just one sentence: over the past 30 years European standards have delivered great benefits for companies, for consumers. They have been based on a unique partnership between European legislators, standard—setting bodies, industry workers and of course civil society groups.  At the heart of the partnership has been a voluntary, demand-led and consensus-driven approach but the standardisation system now, of course, faces a number of challenges: the increasing speed of change in the global economy, the growing role of ICT and the increasing importance of services, to name just a few of them.  So last year we set out a new direction in this area, calling for a system that is agile and that is timely. At its heart we launched a joint initiative on standardisation. We want a system that is both inclusive and collaborative, a system that taps the potential of ICT and services and, above all, a system that can set priorities and deliver results. I am pleased to see that the report recognises the importance of standardisation and welcomes at the same time the joint initiative. The report will fit into our annual Union work programme on European standardisation for next year, which is currently under discussion. The upcoming interinstitutional dialogue early next year will also be an opportunity to further discuss the topics of mutual interest. As I cannot, as you understand, now comment on the whole report, I will focus on four key aspects that the rapporteur also mentioned, the importance of inclusiveness, transparency, ICT standardisation and standard essential practices. Let me start with inclusiveness. Standards, as was said, affect everybody so everybody should have the possibility to have their opinion heard and taken into account when standards are prepared. The report acknowledges that the 2012 Regulation on standardisation has made improvements here so we will continue in this direction.  We have asked the European standardisation organisations – the European Committee for Standardization (CEN), the European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization (CENELEC), and the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) – as well as all national standardisation bodies to intensify their cooperation with stakeholders. We are asking them to adapt their internal rules and their internal procedures to help the work of stakeholders’ organisations. In the joint initiative there are three actions focused on inclusiveness. They target inclusiveness at national, European and international level. Work on this has started and is progressing smoothly so far. Second, on transparency, I agree with the report that we need to increase the transparency, accountability and timelines of the standardisation system. I know the report called us to address the reasons behind the decreasing citation of references of harmonised standards in the Official Journal. We are working closely with the standardisation organisations to find practical and durable solutions. Third, on ICT standardisation. Most people know how frustrating it is and can be to buy digital technology only to find that it cannot connect to other devices. ICT standards ensure that these devices work together seamlessly. Last year we adopted a strategic and political plan on ICT standardisation priorities. It is focused on five key areas: 5G, the internet of things, cloud computing, cyber security and data technologies.  We are working closely together with the standardisation community to implement the actions in the time frame indicated. Success depends on high level commitment from a broad stakeholder base. This includes Member States, industry of course, standard—setting organisations and the research community. Finally, my last point, I agree that we need to ensure that industry can rely on an effective licencing system. We need a balanced licencing system for technologies endorsed in standards, in other words, standard essential patents. This system should provide for growth and efficient access to these technologies while at the same time ensuring that there are adequate incentives for research, development and innovation. We are currently working on how to improve the licencing environment and provide clarity on an SEP licencing environment and fair, reasonable and non-discriminatory practices. Once again let me thank the honourable Member for such an excellent report. I hope I can count on your continued support and engagement in the coming years on this very important issue.

name: Pavel Telička
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, first of all I would like to say that I appreciate the work of the rapporteur, especially her sound focus on the transport sector. The question of standardisation is, in fact, absolutely key if we want to achieve a modern, interoperable, single European transport area. The problem is that one of the failures of the internal market is that we have not managed to confront the fragmentation of that market, with different national standards, so our companies, whether in the logistics or freight sectors, often have to cope with different national documents each time they cross a border. At a time when the transport sector is cutting down emissions and becoming much more digitalised and intermodal, at a time when the Commission has put forward the mobility package, we definitely need an interoperable, free-flow-of-data sector which will provide for the uptake of new technologies, like, for example, electric vehicles. We see too that standards now encompass the ICT standards, and this is an absolutely key area, and one in which we would like to encourage our citizens, too, to go intermodal – to use something that is called integrated ticketing. One final remark: I would expect the Commission to see this as an external plea to provide, in its proposals, for intermodal interaction based on free flow of data and everything that comes with it.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - President! Madame la rapporteure, I would like to thank you for your excellent work and the cooperation you have shown in the work. There has really been a report that has really added value, and I can also say that it will be of strategic importance for the future. This report explicitly highlights how key standardization systems are to realizing the potential of the internal market and how important they can be for competitiveness. Without going into full detail or repeating what was said in front of me, I just want to draw attention to a few aspects. Firstly, on the future of European standardization. When we talk about this issue, the question arises as to how to approach it, what the review of this system should be. Well, we can say that the current system is relatively well regulated. So we need to touch without throwing away the current results. So we cannot make a radical change that would weaken the main element of the current system. At the same time, I would also like to mention as an aspect the importance of involving everyone in the standardization process. Be it a national organization, standards bodies and their cooperation. Another aspect is how important it is for everyone involved to have access to it. That is, for standards to be understood by those to whom they apply. Let us also not forget that not everything can be standardized. These standards must not distort competition, and it is precisely by increasing competition that barriers must be removed. It is important that we involve all stakeholders, those involved in research and development and innovation, and everyone in this process. And one last aspect: enforcing the FRAND principle throughout the process. This is a good report, with balance points, which I support.

name: Presidente. –
text: To accept the "blue card" questions, we are waiting for the round of speeches by the political groups to be completed, then of course we will be able to accept them.

name: Christel Schaldemose
text: for the S&D Group. - Sir. Chairman! In everyday life, we rarely think about the fact that there are standards everywhere, even though many of them are very important to us. Just think if the light bulb did not fit the lamp, if the screw did not fit the nut, and if the USB connector only fit a few PCs. Last year, the Commission presented a standardization package with a number of initiatives. All of this is something that will make the European standardization system work well and efficiently, which is absolutely necessary for a well-functioning internal market. For us Social Democrats, standardization work is important, and we therefore fully support the entire European standardization work. I was the Social Democrats' rapporteur on the standardization legislation we made back in 2012. But we also have a few important messages for the effort. We Social Democrats believe that standardization can neither must nor must replace legislation. Legislation is still needed to set the framework for e.g. secure products, for privacy and for the involvement of non-commercial interests. We also see that there is a particular challenge to standards in the digital age. We need to have a flexible and sustainable and inclusive standardization system, but it is also important that we get e.g. citizens and consumers when it comes to rolling out digital single market standards. It is therefore important that there is a strategic approach to the entire standardization work.
