We mean e.g. also, when it comes to privacy, that it is important that we have standards for the entire design phase, so that we get a high and important level of protection for consumers already in the design phase, and in this regard, standards are absolutely crucial. So we back that up. Finally, I would like to thank Marlene Mizzi for a good report and add that standardization work is something we must ensure works effectively for the sake of the interior. market.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Club.- Mr President, the adoption of harmonized and simple European standardization policies with the aim of achieving the right balance between national, European and global dimensions is important, above all, in the context of the final establishment of the digital single market.European conservatives and reformists believe that such standardization must be a bottom-up process, driven by specifically identified needs put before the legislature by industry representatives, rather than overly ambitious politicians who have little to do with production.Our group opposes the growing politicization of the standardization process and wants the industry to be the one to lead the processes that primarily concern it.However, I must point out that a balance has been struck in this report, and that is the approach we welcome.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, standardisation remains quite a technical topic. However, if you talk to people then you hear that people are quite annoyed at having different plugs and different cables for each device that they have, and this is all due to a lack of standards. The EU needs to have an effective and proactive market-driven standardisation policy if we want to be leaders in innovation, the leaders of the race for 5G and for the Internet of Things. This sector is very fragmented, with many proprietary and semi-closed solutions and a multitude of standards. However, if we think about what the Internet of Things is all about – devices communicating with other devices – it is difficult to see how we can do this without standards. I believe that the more open standards we have, the more innovation we have. However, the discussion on this report has shown that we all talk about open standards but we all have different views about what ‘open’ really means. Can we truly call a standard open just because the standardisation process was inclusive enough? Or what about the outcome of the standard? The point of setting standards is that other companies will be able to build their innovations upon them. At least this report acknowledges that there are different business models out there, but I do think the Commission should promote solutions that ensure that different business models can co-exist. If all standardisation initiatives are based on royalties, for instance, where does it leave open-source licensing? As open source can be shared in an unlimited manner, it is not really compatible with royalty-based models. This report is therefore a good start for discussion, but I hope that it is not the end of it.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this report calls for the harmonisation of European standards, an unnecessary proposal which I cannot support. The UK already has a high standard of products which are recognised across the world as being trustworthy and high quality. This is a tradition that existed long before we joined the European Union or it was created. Creating a European standard puts this reputation at risk, as not all Member States are yet able to produce products and services at the same high standard. Indeed, even testing centres for EU standards cannot yet guarantee that products produced under this proposal are all of the same quality. This is dangerous and it could serve to drive down standards and create an atmosphere of mistrust. It is a good job that we in the United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union before irresponsible European law can have a detrimental effect on our economy.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, businesses and social actors need standards. These standards are decisive instruments for all economic and social actors. They need to be effective and market-oriented, in order to foster growth and innovation. They also improve, if established in the common interest, competitiveness, quality and performance, and promote consumer protection, business development, conditions for workers and concern for the environment. They are also - and it is essential to remember this - a voluntary step by States, which is a positive step. This approach is ultimately quite contradictory with the very centralizing aspect of the single market project, unfortunately defended with too much ardor in this text. It is above all cooperation between nations, which I hope, that can promote this type of voluntary approach. In this, I could support certain orientations of this report, but companies and social actors also need stability, and these standards, as useful as they are, must not become obstacles to development, either through chronic instability, either by becoming a real obstacle course or an economic brake for companies already bloodless because of a strong organized economic deregulation, finally, or by becoming the result of strong pressure from particular interest groups. Here we come to the crux of the matter: to entrust the Commission, organizations, agencies or even single standards poles with the establishment of these standards is a strategic error. This excessive centralization is contrary to the common interest. It does not then become a beneficial solution for anyone or, therefore, for far too few people.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I think the report that Mrs Mizzi tabled and that was drawn up with our shadow rapporteurs is good. It may be better than the debate today. So I just want to add three points. Firstly: I believe that standards are created on the basis of private law cooperation between the institutions grouped together in the standardization organizations. That is why there is no connection with public legislation, and you may have to say that to the European Court of Justice at one point or another. Standards created under private law have nothing to do with legislation - colleagues here at the company have also pointed this out. Secondly: …. Ms. Parker is leaving now - it would be a shame because I could have explained to her how large ... companies from the UK like Vodafone came to the European continent by taking over some parts of the market because European standards allowed them to participate. I think it is outrageous that this economic coincidence is neglected here, and I think they will pay a high price for this, because without these common standards for the whole internal market, companies that operate in a smaller marketplace will be cut off. These standards allow big companies and small companies, all over Europe, to take the part of the market they want to have, and therefore I think they are also in the interest of companies from the country which Ms Parker comes from and which is leaving the European Union . Then I would like to add one more point. I think my colleague Gáll-Pelcz mentioned it: One topic in the area of ​​standardization is currently the so-called FRAND standard, which allows all parties involved in standard-essential patents to have access under fair conditions. From my point of view, this process should be strengthened so that we will continue to do the same in the future Conditions for all market participants received.Overall, thank you again for the competent processing of the report.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Mr President, please understand that sometimes I also use a blue card for keynote speakers because I want to know the views of the political groups.Although I am lucky in this case because my colleague Schwab is a very good representative of the People's Party.So I would like to add my question now, very briefly.Mrs Gállné Pelcz mentioned the issue of accessibility.Since one of the most exciting initiatives of the European Union is the 'smart villages' initiative, I ask how much of this current report can be extended to the special needs of rural areas and villages?

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Szanyi, thank you very much for the question.In fact, we have a great interest in digitally opening up rural areas everywhere in the European Union - regardless of whether that applies to your country or my country.And I believe that we not only have to have the necessary infrastructure for this, but also provide standards that can be used by companies - regardless of their size.It is therefore a good thing that we have not stipulated a definition of so-called open standards here in this report that goes beyond the definition made in Regulation 1025/2012.I think this is a good way to enable rural regions to be connected to the digital infrastructure.I hope that has answered your question.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to welcome the proposal for a report on standardization, given that standards are tools that contribute to a fair balance between the European and international national dimensions. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, our colleague, Mizzi, and the other rapporteurs on their balanced report. Personally, I have made several amendments, through which I have tried to emphasize the importance of standards for the functioning of the internal market, in order to strengthen fair competition; obviously, and for consumer protection. We also proposed that the European standardization system be coherent and easy to apply, especially for SMEs. SMEs need to have access, be involved in negotiating standards and, if they do not have the information, they will be scared and will have bureaucracy and additional costs. I also believe that the harmonization of standards is particularly important, even if one of our colleagues said that we should not talk about harmonization. Sure. I also insist, Commissioner, that we talk about these standards in the negotiation of trade agreements with third countries, if we want the internal market not to be at a disadvantage. It is important that all European institutions, Member States, stakeholders communicate the state of play of standardization and, of course, future proposals on standardization. I support the report and I also support the proposal for the international forum proposed by our rapporteur, because it is very important for the future of the European Union and I hope that, in implementation, no obstacles and costs will be created, especially for SMEs.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE).
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues ... and above all, to my colleague Mizzi, who has done and is doing an excellent job with this report, we must thank her. On June 1, 2016, the European Commission presented this package of communications in which it sets out its vision of how the creation of European standards should evolve in the coming years. Within this, there are some priority issues in our Committee on the Internal Market - which continues to work on them - such as, for example, 5G, computing work in the cloud, the internet of things, big data technologies and cybersecurity. Both the Commission's general package on European standardization and the Communication, adopted in April 2016, on information and communication technology standards will provide the harmonization that we have been demanding for so long in this sector. With this, we are taking another step towards a common regulatory framework, which is capable of uniformly adapting to the evolution of technological and logistical advances that is developing around it. It is essential that this initiative be supported, since it is necessary to have cohesion in these policies, which will not only benefit the Member States by providing a regulatory framework at European level, but - which is most important and most interesting at this time - will contribute great benefits to both consumers and businesses. As I defended in previous speeches in this Plenary - and this is how I have been defending in the work of the Internal Market Committee - the unification of standards at European level is an indispensable condition to overcome market fragmentation and protect ourselves from the external threats that threaten us. in this ambit. I would say to my colleague Andreas Schwab that we must not waste time, as he has done, with MEP Parker: they are so fiercely anti-European. You have to do it with the British. my dear Andreas: the British who really want to continue to have a privileged relationship with us, with the European Union.We have to dedicate ourselves to this.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, allow me at the beginning to thank my colleague Mizzi, who has produced and who today brings to our attention a report which clearly highlights the importance of standardization for the proper functioning of the single market, to protect both consumers and businesses. The many differences between the systems of national rules represent today an obstacle to the free movement of goods and to healthy competition, creating significant administrative burdens and limiting the freedom of choice for consumers. I believe that the European Union must therefore invest more in regulatory harmonization processes, to be developed also with the support of all interested parties. And, first of all, I believe in the first place that a common European strategy must prove itself to be proof against small and medium-sized enterprises, which will be the main beneficiaries of new European rules. One of the main challenges to be overcome is that linked to the digitization of our society. The development of common standards in the field of new information technologies will undoubtedly strengthen the competitiveness, interoperability, security and sustainability of our digital infrastructures: essential conditions for the development of a single space of opportunity for European citizens. Finally, I am convinced that greater coherence will also strengthen the European Union's negotiating position in international trade agreements and will allow Europe to play a leading role in promoting its own standards around the world.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Bieńkowska, we need to give new impetus to standards, because such a development will benefit consumers, businesses and the European economy. Promoting the European standardization hub with a global impact is indeed an ambitious goal and will give the European economy a lead. But it can be done with steady steps and a plan to support priority areas, such as the construction sector. If the standards eventually lead to higher quality, it is likely that in the future we will avoid tragedies like the one in the Tower of London. Standards are mainly an extremely important tool for the functioning of the single market and -of course- the digital single market. They promote innovation, increase the quality of services and products, ensure consumer safety and enhance competitiveness. In the Committee on Industry we unanimously approved the report in which I represented the European People's Party. In fact, we expect the Internet of Things, data protection and cyber security to create a technological backbone so that we can develop important areas. It is therefore essential to ensure that companies of all sizes, large and small, can work together in a mutually beneficial way. It is especially important to protect small businesses, ensuring equal access and creating the conditions that will promote innovation.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: - Mr President, common standards are an important tool for the functioning of the single market. The maintenance and further development of the European standardization system is gaining in importance with the growing influence of information and communication technologies, where it will be necessary to place increasing emphasis on ensuring their interoperability. European standards must be developed in a transparent and inclusive way. I welcome the fact that, in emphasizing the proper involvement of the various stakeholders in the standardization process, the rapporteur has also remembered both consumer organizations and organizations representing people with disabilities. I also agree with the rapporteur that standards, as a voluntary market-driven instrument that sets out technical requirements and guidelines, cannot replace political decisions. Political decisions, such as the level of health, safety or environmental protection, should remain with the legislator. I will therefore support my colleague Marlene Mizzi's report and I would also like to thank her for the work she has done on it.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I will vote in favor of this report because I am leading a working group in the European Parliament that is focused on international financial reporting standards and I have a pretty clear picture of the importance of standards for consumer, investor and consumer protection. to facilitate trade and investment in the internal market and internationally. I would like to emphasize in particular the attention paid to the quality of standards, based on transparency and dialogue, and I urge the introduction of the practice of impact assessments for any kind of standards that are developed that effectively take into account the consequences for different economic and economic actors. social. It is also important to follow the standards. Those who do not meet the standards, in fact, apply their own standards. I thank the rapporteur and thank the European Commission for its work in this area.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to commend this report and congratulate Mrs Mizzi on her. I am ready to support her. Like most of my predecessors, I consider the issue of standardization in Europe to be very important. From my point of view, this is no further unnecessary administration, because, as one of my colleagues here has pointed out, these standards are voluntary in private law and are essential in creating a single market. I would like to call on the Commissioner here to really make the Commission as ambitious as possible in this matter, so that we can really strengthen the adoption of technical standards for individual products, and thus create a single market. So these standards are not an unnecessary administration for me, but on the contrary they are something that we are gradually completing the single market and enabling the free movement of goods and their de facto possibilities of sale in any part of the European Union. I also very much appreciate that this report talks about the digital market. I consider it extremely important to strengthen the interoperability of individual digital resources at the time of digitization. What is not fully addressed in the report is the question of the body that should adopt these standards, whether to maintain the current structure of the bodies that adopt these standards, or whether to consider a new European Standardization Center as envisaged by the European Commission.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as a result of new technologies and the progressive integration of digital solutions in industrial production on a global level, as well as the rapidly changing international context, the regulatory instruments are changing rapidly, and it is necessary to give a new impetus to give response to the needs of industry, consumers, workers, environmental organizations and other stakeholders. In the plan presented by the Commission, the joint initiative on standardization must be accompanied by studies of economic and social impact. In fact, I believe that the standardization process must go beyond the single economic aspects. A holistic approach is needed, in which the objectives of SMEs, consumers and citizens - especially those relating to economic, social, health and environmental issues - are fully integrated. And it is therefore essential that the entire Commission package aims at creating a single and coherent European standardization system, which adapts to a constantly evolving context and offers benefits above all for consumers and businesses.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, the single digital market certainly requires standardization and standardization, because only then can we have the development of technologies, especially in the field of communication and information. Rightly so, five priorities are emphasized: 5G, cloud computing, the Internet of Things, data technologies and cybersecurity. At the same time, the Commission must take the decisions and proposals of the European Parliament seriously. In addition, there must be consultation, involving small and medium-sized enterprises, local authorities, civil society and, of course, consumers themselves, because only then can we proceed to a process where standardization and standards will truly support the economy itself. . It is an optional process, but at the same time necessary, and that is why we should not impose standards and especially standardization and harmonization on the measures of large European or American multinational companies.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr. President, I personally support this report because I believe that it is very important to have quality norms and standards, primarily because it will make our economy more competitive and global. Our consumers will be better protected because they will be sure to buy products of the same quality. And also what I would like to point out that several important projects that the European Union is planning today for the future after 2020, and it is about the Energy Union, require quality norms and standards, because communication between market participants in the electricity market, communication of citizens to distribution network, communication between system operators will not be satisfactory if these standards are not interoperable and are not open just as colleague Mizzi pointed out in her report. And I would like to look back at the report of my colleague Parker, who unfortunately left. The UK, which she said leads in standards, still has tensions different from the rest of the European Union, using imperial units rather than an international system. So we have to convert miles to meters and we also have to carry adapters if we want to connect our computer to the network.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Honourable Members for this very interesting discussion. For years Europe has been in the lead when it comes to creating standards and it must stay like this. If we do not create our own standards in Europe, others will do it globally. It is key here that our standards should become a global standard. I very much agreed with Mr Schwab when he said that those outside the system who will not participate in creating European standards will pay the price sooner rather than later. I also agree that standards are crucial for the integrity of the internal market. We are doing our best under our joint initiative launched last year to avoid the fragmentation of the single market. The joint initiative, that was broadly welcomed by all of the partners and all of the stakeholders of the Standardisation System – if I may just repeat this – is there to create a system that is inclusive, collaborative and a symbol for the companies, a system that taps the potential of IT and services, but above all a system that can set priorities in areas such as e-health, smart energy and intelligent transport systems. For example, connected automated vehicles will significantly benefit from our proposed prioritisation. Thank you very much again for this discussion. I will keep you updated and look forward to our interinstitutional dialogue later this year. Let us work together on the future of the European Standardisation System because this is crucial for our citizens and for our industry.

name: Marlene Mizzi
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for their contributions to this debate and in particular to the shadows and to the European Commission. Standards are there to guarantee that products are fit for purpose, work smoothly and reliably together, providing high quality and safety safeguards for our citizens. They are important for consumers and companies, for the interoperability of products and for providing economies of scale by keeping markets open and avoiding lock-in with given providers or products. Therefore, I hope that this report will not be condemned to paper and never see the light of day. I also hope that the Commission, the European standardisation organisations and Member States will implement and enforce its recommendations. So, in particular, I would like to reiterate: it is important to enhance the synergies and coordination between all stakeholders; develop inclusive, sustainable, safe and high-quality standards with fair access and treatment of all stakeholders; improve the accessibility and transparency of the standardisation process; remove the de facto obstacles to an effective involvement of Annex III organisations; create an easy-to-use single point of access to standards; monitor international ICT standardisations and promote the European regulatory model and interests at international level; clarify the core elements of an equitable, effective and enforceable licensing methodology based on FRAND; and prepare a European register listing existing European standards and ongoing standardisation work to avoid duplication of work. And finally, to raise awareness and knowledge about standards, introduce professional standardisation courses, and develop standardisation guidelines for policymakers. Last, but not least, I welcome the Commission’s decision to involve the European Parliament as a signatory to the joint initiative for standardisation.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow at 12.00.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: signed up. - The European standardization system is one of the key elements for the completion of the single market. The EU urgently needs a single, modern and flexible standardization system to strengthen fair competition and innovation globally. The implementation of this unique system will generate benefits and predictability for consumers and businesses. I call on the Commission to align all the initiatives proposed in recent years so that a European standardization platform can be developed as soon as possible, in which standards can be developed in a timely and open manner. The Commission must also propose concrete measures to speed up the process of setting more information and communication technology (ICT) standards for multiple policies, as it has already done for five areas: 5G technologies, cloud computing technologies, the Internet of Things, data technology and cybersecurity. I believe that standards need to be developed with the support of industry and public authorities, but also of consumers, workers and citizens. SMEs, consumers and citizens need to be involved in this process. Last but not least, I believe that standards must impose guidelines and technical requirements that can contribute to the implementation of European legislation and policies.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral answer to the Commission on the increase in HIV, tuberculosis and HCV epidemics in Europe, by Françoise Grossetête, Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu, Urszula Krupa, Frédérique Ries, Kateřina Konečná, MartinHäusling, Piernicola Pedicini and Mireille D'Ornano, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000045/2017 - B8-0321 / 2017).

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: Author. - Mr President, in 2015, almost 30,000 newly diagnosed HIV infections were reported in 31 countries of the European Union and the European Economic Area. At the same time, it is estimated that 120,000 people in the European region have developed multidrug-resistant tuberculosis, and in general, viral hepatitis is one of the most serious threats to public health. These three infections require long-term and permanent programs that often target multiple populations at the same time. If prevention services were integrated, synergies and savings could be achieved. The current EU Action Plan on HIV / AIDS expired at the end of 2016. The ECDC Framework Action Plan for Tuberculosis in the European Union dates from 2008 and needs to be updated. To date, there is no comprehensive plan to combat hepatitis C at European Union level. At the Informal Meeting of EU Health Ministers in Bratislava on 4 October 2016, Member States agreed to support the development of a framework for an integrated European Union policy on HIV / AIDS. tuberculosis and hepatitis C. This policy should be appropriate to the specific nature of the epidemics in the European Union and neighboring countries, in order to strengthen the policy response to these diseases. In its Communication entitled "Next steps for a sustainable European future", the Commission emphasized its continued efforts to eradicate HIV / AIDS and tuberculosis and reduce hepatitis by 2030. We have asked and continue to ask: What concrete steps does the Commission plan to take to has it fulfilled what it set out in the above-mentioned communication with regard to the goal of sustainable development 3 - "ensuring a healthy life and promoting well-being for all people of all ages"? Secondly, how is the Commission's plan responding to the Bratislava agreement between EU health ministers on 4 October on developing a framework for HIV / AIDS and hepatitis C policy? And thirdly: how does the Commission intend to increase funding to combat tuberculosis in developing EU countries by providing financial assistance to Member States, which should partially cover the high costs of tuberculosis treatment? Commission representatives, how many times have we dealt with this matter here? Honestly, your inaction in this matter is becoming unacceptable. Already in 2015, I called on you to create a new concept for combating these diseases for the years 2014-2020. I myself wrote several written questions to the Commission on this subject. And what have we seen so far? Nothing at all. Always just evasive words and promises that have not been fulfilled. And not to mention ridiculous answers to my written questions. We have already asked the three Dutch, Slovak and Maltese Presidencies to resolve the situation. Now our fourth presidency is beginning and the solution is nowhere to be seen. In the meantime, the situation has worsened much and we have also gone through the strategies that were still running two years ago. Not only is the situation outside the European Union deteriorating for us, but the catastrophic situation is beginning to be in the immediate vicinity, for example, with regard to HIV. Our ECDC's annual epidemiological reports on cross-border disease threats are eloquent proof of this. Member States have already understood that we urgently need an updated EU framework policy to combat HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis C for the period 2016-2020, which would address the specific nature of the epidemic not only in the European Union but also in the Eastern Partnership countries. However, 8 months have passed since the informal meeting in Bratislava in October 2016! When will the Commission finally understand that tackling these three diseases requires a comprehensive strategy that targets the overlapping sections of the population, even the poorest? In addition, the first WHO Global Health Strategy against Viral Hepatitis (2016-2021), adopted by the World Health Assembly in May 2016, emphasizes the key role of universal health care and aims, in line with the Sustainable Development Goals, to reduce new cases by 2030. viral hepatitis by 90% and eventually eradicate viral hepatitis as a public health problem.It will be very difficult for the Commission to monitor progress towards the sustainable development goals for viral hepatitis, as data on the monitoring of the disease in the Member States are often missing or insufficient.The approach to combating viral hepatitis at EU level is still inconsistent and is being addressed on a country-by-country basis.Unfortunately, the Commission's response is none.We are not fulfilling our international obligations, I ask you, Commissioner?These diseases are relatively easy to prevent, but if they do occur, they are already very difficult to deal with.By not doing this, we are losing billions of euros from the health and social care system in the subsequent treatment of their chronic phase.And it is imperative to work together at a transnational and interdisciplinary level to tackle these epidemics.And we want to challenge you to that.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, frankly I disagree with Ms Konečná who said that the Commission is not doing anything now. It is unfair.  I am pleased to attend this plenary session and to talk about HIV, hepatitis and tuberculosis. Let me stress that I fully share your concerns about the need for concrete action to address these three diseases. It was our proposal, from the Commission side, to link HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis C. Why? Because the same vulnerable groups, the same people, are affected by those diseases: the poorest people, homeless people, people in prison and so on, people with a stigma – and we have joined forces in saying yes, it is time to show synergy. These diseases continue to cause suffering to millions of citizens across the European Union. More than five million people in the EU suffer from hepatitis C. This is very serious. More than 100 000 people need lifelong treatment for HIV/AIDS, and 30 000 people become infected every year. The latest figures show an increase in HIV across the whole of Europe, from Cyprus and Malta to Germany, Ireland and Lithuania. The economic crisis since 2008 has worsened the situation: in parallel with a deterioration in social and economic determinants, inequalities are on the rise. Tuberculosis is a social illness in this respect, and all these aspects show the seriousness of the situation.  In recent years we have seen a 40% increase in new core infections of tuberculosis and HIV, and the rate of drug resistance to tuberculosis remains high. In addition to human suffering, these diseases pose serious challenges to our health systems and to our economy and our society across Europe, yet much of this suffering is preventable. The message is clear: greater efforts are needed to reduce both the suffering and the costs that these diseases inflict. As you know, health ministers exchanged views on these issues last October and they recognised the challenges, in particular with regard to tuberculosis and HIV/AIDS. It was our common job, together with the Council, to discuss these issues. Just a couple of weeks ago at the Health Council, I also spoke to ministers about the need to intensify concrete action and strengthen implementation efforts to prevent the spread of these diseases. I had very comprehensive debates with the new director of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), speaking about possibilities to renew our activities and once again to strengthen collaboration between Members States. In answer to your first question: what concrete action is the Commission planning to take to give effect to the commitments made in the abovementioned communication pertaining to Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 3, ‘Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages’? Let me assure you that the Commission remains fully committed to helping Member States achieve the goal of ending HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis and reducing viral hepatitis by 2030. The Commission reaffirmed this commitment last November in its communication entitled ‘Next steps for a sustainable European future’. In this communication you can see our positions and our activities. Next year the Commission will present further measures to address HIV/AIDS, hepatitis and tuberculosis as a follow-up to this communication, and in the course of the next year we will put forward action plans to that end. In the meantime, the Commission is already fostering cooperation at EU level with Member States and stakeholders and is supporting projects and research in this area. The Commission has re-launched the HIV/AIDS, hepatitis C and tuberculosis think-tank. It has also enlarged the scope of the former HIV Civil Society Forum, which now encompasses all HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis C organisations. We have started to discuss very concrete measures, and how to move in the right directions. Together we will seek to identify concrete steps to scale up our prevention and testing programmes, to reach out to the most vulnerable and to address social inequalities and determinants. To succeed, I believe we need to combine health instruments with social instruments and work together across health, social and education policies. I will be more than happy to see a very comprehensive approach, together with the European Parliament and Member States, in this direction. Integration of prevention, treatment and care for HIV/AIDS plus tuberculosis and hepatitis should become standard practice across Europe, and we will look at how to do more and to encourage Member States to move in such a direction. As for your second question, which I need not repeat: firstly, the Commission’s EU health programme is supporting action, in particular, to target the most vulnerable. The Commission is currently shaping a new joint action called ‘Integrate’ with Member States in improving the quality of prevention and care for HIV/AIDS, viral hepatitis, tuberculosis and sexually transmitted infections. Starting in September, for three years, this joint action will help Member States develop policies to integrate early diagnosis and care for HIV, viral hepatitis, tuberculosis and other infections. With a co-funding of EUR 2.5 million, this joint action will promote capacity-building, training, exchange of good practices and the practical piloting of tools for diagnosis and linkage to care – encouraging Member States to use such opportunities and, of course, to do their best at national level. The joint action will notably expand the use of tools to increase testing and linkage to care in healthcare facilities and to facilitate the expansion of HIV home self-testing and home sampling programmes. Secondly, the Commission is also strongly committed to continuing to support research for HIV, tuberculosis and viral hepatitis. Under the Horizon 2020 Programme, we support development of novel preventative and therapeutic tools to fight this infection. Research into the development of prophylactic vaccines accounts for over half of our investment in these diseases: EUR 60 million for research on HIV vaccination and EUR 26 million for tuberculosis vaccines. Thirdly, on the subject of vaccines, to ensure that citizens fully benefit from existing vaccines and other medicines, it is important to make them more accessible and affordable to all, and therefore to encourage Member States to engage in swifter cooperation, exchanging practices and experiences, and to increase transparency in the pricing of medicines, for example by using the European Integrated Price Information Database (EURIPID) supported by the Member States. I also encourage Member States to use joint procurement agreements as a potential means of reducing shortages of vaccines. Fourthly, we also need to optimise the use of the existing regulation to allow innovative medicines that bring therapeutic added value to reach patients faster, and to explore fully the opportunities that joint procurement offers. I have also asked the Expert Group on Safe and Timely Access to Medicines for Patients (STAMP) to move in that direction. Fifthly and lastly, the need to support measures to address multidrug resistance to tuberculosis as well as HIV and hepatitis is enshrined in the new Commission Action Plan to reduce anti-microbial resistance, which the Commission adopted last Thursday. The Commission is engaged in establishing an integrated and systematic monitoring system for the 2030 Agenda to keep track of progress and to respond to the United Nations reporting requirement. It is also necessary to agree on common indicators. On your third question, our action does not stop at the borders of the European Union. The Commission is also fully engaged in international cooperation to address HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis. I attend a lot of international meetings at which we discuss together common steps. The Commission supports global health initiatives such as the global fund to fight tuberculosis and malaria. The EU has actually recently increased its financial support to this fund and to the global alliance for vaccines and immunisation, the co-called GAVI Alliance. I have high expectations for the first global ministerial conference on ending tuberculosis next November in Moscow, which I will attend. In addition, all three EU institutions have recently signed the European Consensus on Development. This consensus commits us to invest in preventing and combatting communicable diseases and securing affordable medicines and vaccines for all. The Consensus is our key external tool for implementing the 2030 Agenda in our development cooperation. I thank the European Parliament for being one of the co-founders of such a consensus and such a document in which we enshrined a lot of initiatives and set out our goals. Mr President, honourable Members, I hope and trust you share my enthusiasm to drive matters forward. Let us work more closely together to eliminate the suffering that HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis cause. It is hard to contemplate the picture we see today. Every day that I am in Strasbourg I see people sleeping on the streets – homeless people, who are in a difficult situation. It is our obligation to change the situation and to ensure that such a picture will disappear in the future.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, three mass killers, this is what HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis C are, today recognized as being, on the European continent, the three main cross-border threats in public health. If hope is reborn with the latest wave of therapeutic innovations, such as the treatment to cure hepatitis C or a possible vaccine against AIDS, in the trial phase, the situation remains alarming: 2 and a half million people in Europe are infected with the AIDS virus, 14 million are infected with hepatitis C and a particularly worrying epidemic of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis is currently affecting eastern Europe. In the face of these threats, it is clearly up to Europe to act. Only effective coordination at European level will enable these epidemics to be overcome. "Every man for himself" is no longer an option. A coordinated response is all the more necessary as these three pathologies present a significant co-morbidity. Their treatment is also associated with a strong social stigma which tends to isolate and make infected patients even more vulnerable. However, despite the situation, these diseases had disappeared from European political priorities, leaving us with particularly old commitments. The HIV action plan ended in December 2016, the tuberculosis action plan dates back to 2008 and no guidelines exist for viral hepatitis. As the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control is sounding the alarm, I call on you, Commissioner - and I know you are very sincere - to put on the table, without delay, this new European strategic framework that you have come to describe us - an integrated, cross-cutting framework that addresses both HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis. I believe in your sincerity. We are here to support you, Mr. Commissioner.This is really important for public health.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, after a long journey and years of hard work I am glad that we are finally having this debate about epidemics in Europe and I would like to thank all my colleagues who contributed to the resolution. I know it means as much to them as it means to me.  The title of the resolution, ‘HIV, TB and HCV epidemics in Europe on the rise’, is suggestive because tuberculosis has existed for millennia and remains a major global health problem which feeds on poverty. In 2015 there were almost 30 000 newly diagnosed HIV infections reported within the EU-EEA region. Around 400 people die too each day in the European region from causes related to viral hepatitis despite the availability of prevention and treatment. This is the painful reality. The cost of HIV, TB and HCV medicines for treatment and for prevention varies from one country to another. As such, all three infections require long-term and sustained programmes, often targeting overlapping population groups. Therefore it is necessary to develop a comprehensive EU policy framework addressing HIV, AIDS, tuberculosis and hepatitis C, as the Member States agreed in Bratislava in October 2016 and because in 2016, all programmes regarding TB, HIV and HCV ended.  I want to draw your attention to the fact that fighting against HIV, TB and HCV epidemics is the responsibility of all the actors involved – the Commission, the Member States, the non-governmental organisations, social organisations and society in general. In addition, victims and vulnerable populations must be at the centre of all efforts, based on close cooperation and coordination amongst all relevant actors. In order to improve HIV, TB and HCV prevention, detection and treatment adherence, the Commission and the Member States need to develop specific programmes and financial support to strengthen work with communities and vulnerable people, especially in developing countries. Without action and funding we cannot fight against these epidemics.

name: Urszula Krupa
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! In the case of tuberculosis, the biggest problem today is multi-drug resistance resulting from the overuse of antibiotics - not only in treatment, but also as antibiotic growth factors in farmed animals - which requires a solution at the central level of the EU, as the number of tuberculosis infections is increasing not only in African or Central European countries. Eastern, but also in rich countries. With over 40 million people infected with HIV, in addition to adequate healthcare organization with lifelong antiretroviral therapy, there is a need for improved diagnosis, which increases the chance of living without AIDS. However, people living with HIV play the most important role in controlling the epidemic, preventing and transmitting HIV to others, which creates a need for their education and the need to inform their sexual partners. On the other hand, the promoted pre-exposure treatment is problematic, as so far there is no clear evidence of the benefits of drug prophylaxis in HIV partners - in a situation where the HIV + partner is in the phase of effective antiretroviral therapy. For many years, after the previous prevalence of infections among injecting drug users, an increase in infections in the MSN group has been observed: from 12% in 2000 to over 75% in 2014, where the conclusions are obvious as to prevention, including the ignored here in Parliament completely - because I have tabled amendments - sexual restraint and patients' responsibility, which is also needed in the case of hepatitis C, where inpatient prevention and addiction prevention is important, but the pointless risky fashion for tattooing and piercings should end, all the more so as effective treatment of HCV is expensive and requires morally unacceptable patient selection.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Commissioner Andriukaitis! It was evident from your commitment that you are really trying everything - and as a doctor, you are also a specialist - to stand by us and support us in our resolution. It really is like this: I come from Germany and you might think that - if you look at the public - AIDS is no longer bad. Because the only thing I can still see with AIDS are certain large-format posters that say: Don't give AIDS a chance, use condoms! You've gotten so used to it that you think it's not that bad with AIDS. It is still a disease that leads to delayed death, but which is fatal. And she is still discriminated against. I'm from Lower Saxony, and just a few years ago I heard that someone had died of AIDS, and in order to improve the memory of the dead and the reputation of the family, it had to be said that they died of cancer, not of AIDS. So it is still the case that having this disease is discriminatory. And that is why it is important to educate and do everything possible, and also to concentrate in research on whether something can be done to cure this disease in general. My colleagues have already pointed out that the connection between AIDS, tuberculosis and hepatitis C is really deadly and really very difficult. And that is why it is important to work together between the different Member States. Tuberculosis - said the Commissioner - is a social disease, it affects poor people. That's true. In the rich countries or in the rich classes in Europe it does not actually occur at all. But in Eastern European countries or especially in poor households it is still totally present and can be really deadly. And that's why it's so important Here, too, to focus on and consider what you can do.And then also - it has already been said - the connection to the multi-resistant germs, where we have a strategy at EU level: This should also be very much in focus.The question remains whether the G20 will deal with it as we would like.Finally, hepatitis C is often not recognized in time, but it can be cured.And that's why it's so important to watch how these diseases develop.I think we are on the right track if we all do what we say here.

name: Margrete Auken
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! Thank you for what has been said. After all, we pretty much all almost agree, so I want to concentrate on one single case, and that is the treatment of hepatitis C. Here we stand with a really well-grown scandal! It is not very expensive to produce the drug to be used to treat hepatitis C, but blood-dripping profits are made on that particular drug. A treatment in Denmark costs e.g. about 450,000 kroner for a single patient, ie. nearby 60,000 euros for a patient. At the same time, we know that in the poor countries where you have come through with some of these compulsory licenses, you have a price that is 99% lower! We came up in February with an own-initiative report on access to medicines, in which we imposed or encouraged or wanted the Commission to do something about these dramatic pricing, which is ruining people and plundering our budgets, and that it is done by ensuring that we get transparency around pricing. How much is research and development? How much is marketing? How much is lobbying in this context? It's about a lot of medicine. How much is it just about someone sitting with a patent and being completely cynically indifferent to people dying? How can we ensure that we get better cooperation between the countries so that we can negotiate some decent prices in place? Not only does this apply to hepatitis C, but the situation is particularly dramatic for this product, which we know can cure people, and it's awful that they do not get it in time so we can save their lives. We must also secure ourselves. Incidentally, I agree with what else has been said.

name: Julia Reid
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, last March the ECDPC and the WHO released data showing that new TB cases and deaths in the 53 countries of the WHO European region declined each year by 4.3% and 8.5% respectively between 2011 and 2015. However, this decline was not mirrored in vulnerable groups for TB infection, such as people living with HIV, prisoners and migrants, where new TB—HIV co—infections increased by 40% over the same period. Of greater concern is that this increase coincides with persistently high rates of drug-resistant TB, which threatens progress towards eliminating TB by 2030. Similarly, the incidence of viral hepatitis was also rising in vulnerable groups. In my opinion, national governments should rapidly implement screening programmes in order to identify those people in need of treatment.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, Commissioner, a comprehensive approach in the fight against HIV, tuberculosis and viral hepatitis is essential today, all the more so in a context of the migration crisis which is increasing the incidence of these diseases. In addition, countries in eastern Europe are heavily affected by multidrug-resistant tuberculosis, against which the strongest antimicrobials are ineffective. However, in three quarters of the existing cases, it is not diagnosed, which is particularly worrying. However, in a third of cases, it is tuberculosis that HIV carriers die, hence the need to support research into new vaccines. The same is true of hepatitis C, for which there is currently no vaccine. In fact, hepatitis C is often diagnosed by chance, which again underlines the need for in-depth screening. Finally, I approve of the idea of ​​European surveillance programs for these infections in order to better target them and better treat the main foci.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! There are already some positive changes in the fight against hepatitis: the possibility of vaccination and effective controls for hepatitis B, potential cure in over 90 percent of cases for hepatitis C. WHO has taken this into account and in 2016 a global strategy and action plan for Europe presented, which should eliminate hepatitis B and C as a threat to public safety and public health by 2030 and thus not only prevent large-scale human suffering, but also contribute to savings in the national economy. Commissioner, in order to know whether health policy decisions and measures are successful and effective, one must have good and reliable data. Thanks to the Dublin Declaration on HIV / AIDS in 2004, this high-quality and comparable data for HIV / AIDS is not only available across the EU, but across the entire WHO European region. These high quality, qualitative and comparable data are currently available, but not for viral hepatitis. You fly blind over Europe, so to speak. I am glad that the European Commission, led by Vice-President Timmermans, has committed itself to helping Member States meet the UN Sustainable Development Goals and that it will provide data to measure progress towards implementation - and You underlined that again today. However, I would like to note that these data are currently hardly available for the goal of combating or eliminating hepatitis. How are you going to make sure that Member States can do that and can you envision getting the Dublin Accord revised for these three communicable diseases?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, HIV, hepatitis and tuberculosis are three diseases that are literally affecting European populations, especially those at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Tuberculosis began to appear again, after many years, in Greece, especially in the first years of the memorandum, at a time when the Greek people were really hit and impoverished and at a time when health spending was also reduced. In addition, hepatitis and tuberculosis are reappearing in Greece, with new cases, in Kilkis, Kavala and other areas, mainly in large numbers of refugees and illegal immigrants who have currently entered the country. The issue today is how to deal with these diseases and, above all, that there should be cheap medicines and that multinationals should not profit at the expense of the poor.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: - (FI) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two thirds of the world's 1.4 billion people living in poverty are women.If fundamental rights are not realized, these women will not have the opportunity to decide on their own bodies, their sexuality and ultimately their future.There is no way they can protect themselves from unwanted pregnancies, STDs or sexual violence, let alone various other infectious diseases.HIV is currently the leading cause of death for women of childbearing age in the world.The greed of others is reflected in the poverty of others and increasing diseases.Lack of contraception and appropriate medicines leads to serious epidemics.What are our biggest challenges in this era?Climate change, communicable diseases and poverty.Is the answer, for example, to the fact that we in Europe are increasingly injecting money into defense instead of responding to these concrete, genuine problems?

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have tabled this resolution in which we call for an integrated plan to effectively combat AIDS, tuberculosis and viral hepatitis C, because in 2015 some 30 000 new HIV infections were diagnosed, because the number of recorded cases of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis in our continent and because there are between 130 and 150 million people worldwide affected by the hepatitis C virus. We believe that facing these battles only at the national level means not understanding the real reasons why these diseases are generated and not even having understood that in order to significantly limit their spread, cooperation between all states on a global level is needed. We can limit AIDS, we can limit tuberculosis and we can also eradicate hepatitis C, but to achieve these results we also need to radically change the relationship between institutions and pharmaceutical companies. We need transparency and reality, Madam President and Commissioner, we need to be represented by people who serve the interests of the people. And then we also want to know why, instead of investing in a pharmacological prevention strategy that could have been adopted by developing a vaccine also for hepatitis C, it was decided instead to focus on an expensive and inaccessible therapy for most citizens. , just because it is more profitable for pharmaceutical companies. Commissioner, you are a doctor, and I am sure you agree with me when I say that these decisions based only on the logic of profit and on the skin of the sick, unfortunately, literally suck. Therefore, I believe that the Commission should be able to change things and, if it does not, it makes itself responsible and co-responsible for these decisions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). - Madam President, the rapid increase in the incidence of serious infections in Europe, such as tuberculosis, HIV and hepatitis, clearly shows to all of us that the risk to the health of European citizens is increasing. Let us focus on the causes of this increase. Young people are still unable to realize the danger of these diseases, as they grew up in an environment that focused more on sexual liberation and less on the risks of transmitting sexually transmitted diseases. Also, with the dramatic increase in migration flows, bodies from countries with substandard health systems have entered Europe uncontrollably, and a large number of cases are observed in these very individuals. The solution I propose is initially a large information campaign, so that citizens realize the problem in its true size. In addition, I consider it necessary to strictly monitor the health of those entering the Union. Finally, I suggest that instead of the dubious value of third-country funding, which often ends up in the pockets of officials, we support health and information centers in these countries to ensure that they do the best job possible.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: - The increase in HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis C is a cause of great concern for us. Fortunately, the specter of these diseases has largely disappeared thanks to the efforts of the innovative medical world. Nevertheless, there are still serious threats to the health of our citizens. An unnecessarily large number of HIV patients still die after being infected with resistant bacteria. Resistant TB strains are proliferating and spreading, while detection is inadequate. Last week, European Commissioner Andriukaitis presented the EU action plan against antimicrobial resistance. The fight against this antibiotic resistance must now be converted into policy more quickly within the European Union. In addition, there should be no political sacred houses! In third countries TB is a major problem and antibiotic use unfortunately irresponsible. Since 1993, the Netherlands has been investigating asylum seekers for tuberculosis contamination. The exemplary approach to TB through preventive screening of every incoming migrant has yielded good results in the Netherlands. Tuberculosis is therefore also rare in the Netherlands. In times of migration, doctors and the government - the RIVM - have also been able to prevent outbreaks in asylum seekers' centers through this targeted preventive screening and to treat many vulnerable migrants in a timely manner. X-rays have been used to check migrants from mostly African countries for TB and have saved the lives of many migrants. Somalia, Eritrea and Ethiopia are high risk areas for TB. A targeted European approach is needed in these times of large-scale migration. Antibiotic resistance and an increase in tuberculosis can lead to a return of the specter of a cure for TB patients in sanatoriums or even in a tent. We as the EU should never allow that. That's why we have to deal with it. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question under Rule 162 (8).)

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question.- You did not mention one serious group, namely undocumented asylum seekers who remain in the country.In many European countries, they are banned from healthcare.It can be said that this could be a big risk in the future.What do you think about the situation of paperless immigrants?

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer.- I am assuming the current situation as we are perfectly on top of it in the Netherlands.You have to be clear about how asylum seekers arrive.You must also ensure that the papers are there.You have to look at it.But today we are talking about public health and that is why I have put forward the approach that I have just said.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Infectious diseases such as HIV, AIDS, tuberculosis and hepatitis C know no bounds. Prevention and treatment should therefore also be something we take care of together and across borders. The challenges are great, also in the EU. We have many who are infected. We have many who die from the diseases, and we have many who cannot be treated properly, not least because we have an antibiotic resistance problem, which is a particular problem for people with tuberculosis. Therefore, a common EU strategy is needed to address these issues. Thank you to the Commission for acknowledging this and for addressing this strategy. We need better data collection from Member States so we know what works. We need a better exchange of experience and more coordination. We need for better and more prevention. We need a massive effort against antibiotic resistance, and then we need more money for this total effort. Let's get started, there's a lot of work waiting!

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Europe has one of the highest standards of health care in the world, and treatment is generally available to all citizens regardless of property status or any other economic or demographic determinant.Nevertheless, Europe has become increasingly aware of the importance of prevention in recent years.The increase in the number of people suffering from AIDS, tuberculosis and hepatitis C that we have been facing in recent years is a sign that we need to work harder on raising public awareness and strengthening public health policies.Our efforts should not be limited exclusively to the Member States, but we must achieve the best possible cooperation in this area and with the surrounding countries, but also with those third countries from which more people migrate to Europe.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, the implementation, since 2010, of the memoranda and the reduction of public expenditure on health in Greece, in addition to the humanitarian crisis, Commissioner, have also created a health poverty zone. The decline in public health spending has resulted in an increase in HIV cases, mainly in 2011-2012, with epidemic features, which was also highlighted in the Council of Europe report on health. Due to malnutrition, poor living conditions, inability and delay in citizens' access to health services, there has also been an increase in cases of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. The inability of patients with hepatitis C to access modern effective drugs, due to high costs, prevents ensuring a healthy life for all. Commissioner, no epidemic has borders and no fence will stop it from spreading. There is an urgent need to remove memorandum policies and austerity policies, ie the causes of these diseases, increase costs, equal access to modern effective treatments, update European programs for these diseases and subsidize the high cost of treatments, in order to eliminate them .

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Madam President, today, as my colleagues mentioned, all three infections affect a large percentage of the population in the Union. I welcome and support this resolution and I congratulate my colleagues for the initiative. I know that you, Commissioner, have already taken steps to fight these epidemics, and I am sure that after this debate you will do even more. Fighting against, and addressing the burden of, these diseases require long-term programmes and sustained efforts, action plans to raise awareness, and prevention. The economic burden of these diseases is putting pressure on the Member States and the costs significantly increase with the progression of the diseases. The situation for hepatitis is particularly acute in the central and south-eastern EU Member States that have some of the highest rates of HCV prevalence in the EU, but where access to screening, diagnosis and treatment is limited. We need to focus not only on access to innovative treatments but also on early detection, better diagnosis and, mainly, prevention and awareness-raising among the populations at risk. Exact data on the incidence of hepatitis across the EU does not exist at the moment. Some patients discover their infection only at the later stages, while others live with the disease without knowing. We need better surveillance of hepatitis in the EU, and patient organisations think we should aim to replicate the Dublin declaration, which had great success in relation to HIV surveillance. In order to minimise the hepatitis disease burden, Member States need to implement action plans, increasing the pool of diagnosed people, increasing access to therapy and increasing screening capacity.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D).
text: - Madam President, HIV, tuberculosis and viral hepatitis outbreaks are major threats to public health, both in the European Union and globally. All three types of diseases often affect the same vulnerable groups. It is therefore logical to manage them jointly through an integrated strategy. Such an approach will bring better and faster results at lower costs. Preventive actions, including educational programs, are clearly the best options for patients, in addition to being the most cost-effective solutions. Significant progress has been made in the prevention and treatment of these diseases, but not all available treatments have had the desired impact, due to the fact that medicines have high prices and stocks are fluctuating. These causes can lead to treatment interruptions. In the case of tuberculosis, such interruptions may contribute to increased antimicrobial resistance. An integrated strategy at Union level can provide answers to some of the current problems and help deliver results.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the worsening of the HIV-AIDS, tuberculosis and hepatitis C epidemics in Europe requires the implementation of targeted, effective and innovative strategies, based on three keywords: prevention, diagnosis and treatment, to which consistent programs must be associated. health education. In the field of treatment, it is imperative to ensure access to innovative medicines. To do this, it is necessary to face the interests of multinational pharmaceutical companies and defend the interests of patients and states. In Portugal, active and systematic screening for infections among injecting drug users and education for risk reduction resulted in a change in consumption habits. Portugal was a pioneer on several fronts in the fight against drug addiction and associated communicable diseases, with the implementation of legislation, structures and innovative programs that produced results. An achievement that the years of the troika and its governments have come to call into question. In relation to new cases of HIV infection, the number of late diagnoses, particularly among heterosexuals, is a cause for concern, so it is necessary to increase the early diagnosis and reduce the undiagnosed fraction of those infected.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: - Madam President! The increase in the incidence of HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis C in Europe is a serious challenge for the European Union in the area of ​​protecting the health and life of its citizens. Here you said - as statistics show, more than 2 million cases of HIV infection in the WHO European region, nearly 70% of people infected with HIV may not know that they are carrying the virus, which poses a risk to other people with whom they have contact, especially sexual contacts . In Europe - tuberculosis: 1,000 people in Europe contract the disease daily despite social changes and improved living conditions. Unfortunately, this disease still takes its death toll. And hepatitis C, which is currently one of the world's largest clinical, diagnostic, epidemiological and social problems, and the main cause of its incidence in the European Union is the problem of drug addiction. The question arises: why, despite so many prophylactic programs, we still have to deal with the fact that more and more people fall ill with you. I think that, first of all, we should update the prevention programs. Secondly, there must be cooperation between states and coordination of programs, especially in the era of cross-border movement of people. Third, education - educating both people who are carriers of these diseases and healthy people, so that they avoid the possibility of infection, campaign and access to modern, good, cheap drugs.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Madam President, every year many countries around the world, including Member States of the European Union, organise events to honour the memory of people who die from infectious diseases such as HIV, AIDS, TB and hepatitis. These events come and go many times, but apathy remains high. Despite the progress made over past decades, infectious diseases such as HIV, AIDS, hepatitis and TB continue to be strongly stigmatised, not only here in the European Union but globally too.  Many people infected and affected by HIV, TB and hepatitis continue to face discrimination and stigmatisation every single day. TB, for example, is one of the most seriously neglected and underestimated health, human-rights and poverty problems of our era. TB is re-emerging in many regions of the world as the gravest threat to global health and well—being. Its direct relationship with HIV and AIDS makes it more of a burden on those populations that are already suffering the devastating social, economic and health impact of HIV and AIDS. Stigmatisation and discrimination are not only tragic in themselves but they also contribute to the further spread of these epidemics, undermining all efforts to control the scourge. We have the responsibility to do more and, in particular, we need to address the taboos that surround infectious diseases. A high percentage of new infections identified every year occur in younger people, and this is worrying. This battle is theirs as much as anyone else’s. Not to work together, and not to consider everyone, is not an option. We should not only consider curing people by treatment but also comprehensively implement preventive measures to ensure that fewer people become infected. The impact of these diseases on overall health status and socioeconomic well-being, especially of the most vulnerable, is vast. Inaction and inadequate action are no longer acceptable. The cost of complacency is far too burdensome. These infectious diseases are a major threat to the rights of the child, adolescents, women and their families, and the social impacts are disproportionate, while the stigma is devastating. We have the opportunity to act, but we need – all together – to act now.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the rise of HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis C is a serious problem for public health in Europe.We must, without a doubt, update the action plans of the European Union, but do not be confused about the origin of the problem.The rise of these diseases is not due to more risky behaviors or the loss of efficacy of certain treatments.It is due to the increase in social inequalities, the increase in poverty and that vulnerable groups are more exposed to risk factors, since they are denied access to prevention and adequate treatment, a real health collapse of which they have theblame cuts policies and private health businesses.Authorize the use of compulsory licenses that lower the prices of drugs, reverse the austerity policies that put our lives at risk.Health is not a business, it is a right.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, is dóigh liom dá gcuirfeá ceist ar shaoránaigh na hEorpa go ndéarfadh an chuid is mó díobh nach bhfuil HIV, TB agus HCV san Eoraip a thuilleadh. Ach ón méid atá cloiste againn, ní hamháin go bhfuil siad ann ach faraor tá na galair seo ag dul i méid – agus is trua sin.  Rud atá an-soiléir ná go dtéann sé lámh le lámh le bochtannas. Ós rud é go bhfuil geilleagar na hEorpa ag fás ar deireadh buíochas le Dia, ba chóir dúinn gach iarracht a dhéanamh teacht ar straitéis chun daoine a ardú as bochtannas agus chun cabhrú leo má bhíonn galar dá leithéid seo acu; go mbeadh siad in ann leigheas a fháil air agus drugaí a fháil ar chostas réasúnta. Is léir go bhfuil costas na ndrugaí ina fhadhb an-mhór agus dá bhrí sin caithfimid dul i ngleic leis an bhfadhb seo.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, one in seven people living with HIV does not know that they are HIV positive and the estimated time between HIV infection and diagnosis is on average four years, which increases the risk of transmission of the HIV virus. almost four times. Some 30 000 new HIV infections were diagnosed in the 31 EU / EEA countries in 2015, with no clear signs of a global decline. In addition to AIDS, tuberculosis and viral hepatitis are also widespread, progress more rapidly and cause significant mortality. A comprehensive EU strategic framework for HIV, tuberculosis and hepatitis B and C above all should be envisaged, taking into account the specific challenges faced by Member States and neighboring countries, where the incidence of HIV and tuberculosis is highest. high. Multisectoral cooperation is therefore needed to ensure the necessary resources to strengthen prevention and treatment activities for vulnerable communities and people.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Madam President, many health systems are failing to meet the demands of the AIDS, tuberculosis and hepatitis C epidemics. The three diseases mainly affect specific populations, such as intravenous drug users and illegal immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa. In combination with the adaptive resistance of strains to drugs, they take on the character of a pandemic. Prevention, information and early diagnosis are priorities. Simultaneously with the timely and systematic administration of appropriate drugs, it is possible to completely reduce new infections in the medium term. Finally, corporate abuses, opaque pricing mechanisms and fictitious pricing that reduce the adequacy and accessibility of treatments and increase mortality must end.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, this is a debate about people's lives. I know you are concerned, you have presented a few things to us here. But do you think that's enough? We talked here about education, information, prevention. Commissioner, I do not know if you know the real situation: it is not just about access to treatment for the three diseases due to prices, it is also about quantity. In my country I saw how hepatitis C patients did not have enough treatment or there was not enough treatment for all patients and someone decided: five hundred, for five hundred we have, the rest not. That means a death sentence. We need an integrated policy, as you said, but we must do it taking into account, not as a colleague said: Western countries, Eastern countries, poorer countries. Due to the mobility of European citizens, all three diseases are communicable. And then we have to make a policy of the European Union, of the internal market and I think that nothing can be more important than the allocation of funds to be a treatment for all patients and to detect diseases from an early stage. Thank you.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Madam President, I would expect an answer from Commissioner Andriukaitis. You see now that it is clear, very shocking, that many people cannot recover from serious illnesses because their bodies are already resistant to antibiotics - and this is a huge problem in Europe. I ask how this has to do with our eating habits, which, paradoxically, the European Union is forcing on us. That we don't know what we're eating. That part of the world that particular meat we eat comes from. Mostly, right, we can talk about large-scale agriculture, where there are actually animal factories. The animals are continuously treated with antibiotics. Unlike small farms, where the farmer’s eyes immediately notice the slightest sign of the disease.
