Infections spread among animals on large farms. So to what extent does this phenomenon cause antibiotic resistance in the European Union?

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, colleagues, I have listened with great interest to the views expressed by this House and I am grateful for all of your valuable insights, especially as I see that we are all like-minded, speaking of possibilities to join our forces, not to separately addressing HIV or hepatitis C or tuberculosis. We need to understand that first of all it is social determinance – a lot of the same people, the same vulnerable groups, poverty and so on – and we need to provide comprehensive measures to protect, prevent, introduce, vaccinate, provide testing and so on and so on. We address those issues in our communication ‘Next Steps for a Sustainable European Future’. Following this communication we will present next year our actions to address those issues. This September we will trigger joint action inviting all the Member States to be onboard and improving the quality of prevention of HIV, tuberculosis, hepatitis and sexually transmitted infectious diseases. Some of you mentioned problems with financial issues and budgetary issues and so on. The Commission is working with Member States to optimise the use of existing regulations and also asking, as I mentioned, the stem group to provide Member States with tools to explain how to use their financial capacities to address those issues. You know we are supporting, through the health programme, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) work on access to innovative medicines and sustainability. This can help Member States to strengthen analytical capacity in areas such as pricing strategies and budgetary imports because it is very important – we know very well – in times of austerity there are a lot of problems around us. This House knows very well that we have only a health programme in our hands. It would be good to discuss the new Multiannual Financial Framework and also draw attention to how to strengthen European Union financial capacities to finance more measures because I depend on those programmes which were adopted in this House, and now it is very difficult to see how to move forward. Speaking of pricing, the Commission’s role is to facilitate cooperation between Member States. This support can cover starter projects, maintenance of databases, collecting national prices. We are using European instruments but Member States do not show a big appetite. It will be also good to encourage Member States to cooperate more closely. I visited all 28 Member States. I had discussions with all national parliaments, with governments, speaking about possibilities to draw attention to the situation on the ground, because we need to cooperate. The Commission will continue to encourage Member States to exchange information on access, pricing and cost containment policies, because it is absolutely crystal clear, we need to trigger our activities. As you mentioned, in Portugal, Luxembourg, The Netherlands, they have a lot of good practices in areas of addressing issues about vulnerable people. I visited the Abrigado Centre in Luxembourg. It was a very good job on the ground for assisting people in need to provide prophylactical measures and syringes, to guarantee confidentiality and fighting against stigma and discrimination. Decriminalisation is also a big issue, speaking about the situation in different Member States. We also need to understand that we need to combine health instruments with social instruments. We have no chance to solve only through instruments of health ministers. We need to have broad social programmes on the ground. We need to encourage local authorities and local communities also to do more and providing the local instruments and especially keeping eyes on the homeless people. It is very painful to see those homeless people living on the streets. We also need to see possibilities to extend our educational programmes. I look forward to working together with you towards achieving our shared aim of eliminating these diseases which damage the lives of so many people. As you mentioned, some people are not aware of the situation. Yes, of course we need to have awareness campaigns, and I ask the ECDC and the EMA also to do more to think how to strengthen our capacity for an awareness campaign, not only one day in one year; we need to continue our efforts on an everyday basis. Enforcement, implementation and possibilities to join our forces: I see only one way in this direction.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 5 July 2017.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Pascal Durand, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal 'Longer product life: benefits for consumers and businesses' (2016/2272 (INI)) (A8-0214 /2017).

name: Pascal Durand
text: protractor. - Madam President, thank you for introducing my intervention by pointing out that we have been waiting for this report for a long time. Indeed, Europe has been concerned for a long time in a sectoral way with the question of the lifespan of products, but this is the first time that we have tried to discuss it transversally and, I would say, from a perspective sustainable, trying to put this issue in its global context. Its global context is the heart of the new economy, it is the heart of the sustainable development of the European Union, quite simply because we touch on the environmental question, we touch on the economic and production question, we touch on the question of consumption and the social question. The fact that we are at the heart of this issue forces us to try to think about this question in a consensual manner. This forces us to try to think about it not by opposing ourselves to each other, by opposing economics to ecology or by opposing social questions to questions of consumption, but on the contrary, it is together that we must resolve this problem. problematic. How to solve it? Quite simply by trying to get out of a logic of a waste society, a disposable society and a waste society. Resources today are precious, all resources, whether it is land, whether it is water, whether it is all the elements that make it possible to produce oil, energy. These resources must be saved. We are therefore faced with the issue of resources. Then there is the climate issue, with our products traveling thousands of kilometers to reach our stores and then enter our homes. There is also the social question. The social issue is the relocation of jobs to Europe, the fact that we are going to produce at a lower cost thousands and thousands of kilometers and that we destroy our industry. The social question is that when we throw away, when we replace and when we no longer repair the products we buy, we cause the loss of know-how, of a craft, and also the loss of “repairability” and service. Tens of thousands of jobs have disappeared on the European continent. The social issue is also that we cannot close our eyes to the conditions under which these products are produced cheaply in countries of the South, in which the exploitation of human beings is absolutely scandalous. Finally, there is the economic question, because to produce at a lower cost products which, in the end, no longer have any quality, for which only the criterion of price counts, we destroy the capacity of our European industry to be among the best in the world, if not the best, with quality products that have been recognized for decades now. Logic would want us to come together to take into account the new economy, the economy of functionality, the economy of use, the economy which means that consumers - especially the poorest - no longer want to be forced to change permanently the products they buy and which break down as soon as the legal guarantees end. We must therefore take this new economy into account. We also need to redevelop the "repairability" of all products placed on the market. We need to make sure that the batteries are no longer stuck, but are screwed in so that we no longer have to throw a phone out when the battery dies. We need to ensure that consumers are informed about the useful life of products and our ability to repair them. That is the whole point of my report, Madam President, Commissioner. This is what we expect from the European Union: to take up this issue fundamental.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Parliament's motion for a resolution on longer product life includes a number of proposals that respond to consumers' experiences of product quality and life. I think I am one of the 90% of EU citizens who would welcome a lifetime on products. Also among the 77% of EU citizens who prefer repair to shopping. The point is to save both our wallets and the environment, which is sometimes at odds with the interests of manufacturers. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to focus on concrete measures, the introduction of a voluntary European label, which would include durability, ecodesign of the product, the possibility of modernization and repairability. In order to be able to create a wear counter, especially for large electrical appliances. Measures against planned product obsolescence and consumer protection against software obsolescence. I would like to point out that these proposals must not turn against increased regulation against small and medium-sized companies, but on the contrary to support them.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: - Madam President, consumer confidence in the durability of products is falling sharply. Consumers are even increasingly convinced that products are deliberately designed not to have a long life. Many European customers would prefer to repair their goods before buying a new one, but in the end they are forced to replace the goods or throw them away due to dissuasive repair costs. Last but not least, people now have minimal information about the durability of products. The most vulnerable victims of the accelerated obsolescence of products are the poorest citizens, who, for financial reasons, choose mainly low-cost products, which break down faster. This report identifies concrete measures that can contribute to longer product life, reduce their environmental impact and lower costs for users, ie to develop a sustainable economic model based on balancing the needs of consumers and traders with positive environmental impacts.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, in the model of the circular economy, it is a given that there is and must be the participation of both citizens and businesses in policy-making, so that we can have products and services that really last and at the same time are of good quality. It is a given that more and more consumers are complaining because the products that exist are problematic, have many defects, are not durable and, when one tries to repair them, it turns out that one pays much more for their repair than those who gave to buy them. Therefore, we must create and support a model that will support both employment in the European Union and the strengthening of small and medium-sized enterprises, and of course we must express our opposition to the "monkey" products on the market, mainly from various Asian countries.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, putting an end to planned obsolescence and demanding quality and durability in products and promoting repair are fundamental measures to guarantee a longer service life for products.In addition, this will have advantages because it will generate new jobs that should be located around consumption, will relieve the pressure on natural resources that are despoiled in the countries of the South and often a source of conflicts and will therefore have to contribute to reducing energy consumption.and also in the fight against climate change.We also think that public administrations should set an example and start demanding durability of products in public procurement and in those products that it will subsidize.I consider this document as a starting point to go further and start a path that is essential to transit, the path of degrowth because the planet has limits.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we must start with a fact: the 'throwaway' production model is no longer sustainable. It is no longer sustainable from an ethical point of view, due to the enormous waste of raw materials; it is no longer sustainable from an economic point of view, because the materials we use are neither infinite nor biodegradable; and it is not sustainable for the citizens, who are fed up with buying goods that don't last. We want to create an economic model in which goods last and can be repaired. We ask to sanction those who resort to planned obsolescence, or to sanction those producers who specifically design goods so that they do not last long. We ask for construction techniques and materials that make repairs easier and cheaper. A citizen must be able to change the damaged part of a mobile phone or appliance at a reasonable cost, without having to throw away the mobile phone or appliance. We ask the European Commission for a legislative proposal to put an end to the throwaway culture.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the rapid depletion of our natural resources and our region's dependence on raw material imports are becoming an increasingly urgent problem. The Union must strive to use resources sparingly, and the move towards a circular and shared economy is an important step. Numerous surveys show that a large proportion of European consumers would like more information about the life expectancy of products or would prefer to repair their products over buying new ones. That is why I would find useful initiatives such as the creation of a voluntary EU label for sustainability and eco-design, or the provision of security updates for operating systems within a minimum period of time. Increasing the life and repairability of products can have a number of environmental, consumer and economic benefits. I welcome the fact that the report covers new opportunities for businesses that can be exploited by the measures.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: - Madam President, many of us have experienced that our device "dies" immediately after the expiration of the warranty. This cannot be accidental and must be banned. As many as 92 percent of French citizens believe that the products they buy are programmed to look for the end. In addition, for example, when the bearing on the washing machine breaks, you have to replace the entire drum because there are no minor spare parts. Sometimes spare parts are so expensive that it is not worth repairing at all. In Germany alone, the number of repair shops fell by 13 percent in one year. It is necessary to ensure the availability and reasonable price of spare parts in case of minor failures on the devices. It has been proven that the introduction of a minimum product label would increase sales of labeled products by 55 percent. Consumers are willing to pay more for product durability. I think this is a problem that needs to be addressed at both national and European level. Research has shown that reuse or repair is much better even than recycling because it creates over 10,000 new jobs and has a better impact on the environment.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Ladies and gentlemen! There is no doubt that the so-called planned failure frequency of devices, i.e. the deliberate shortening of the life of products, is a completely harmful phenomenon. Consumers are losing out because they are forced to buy new products too quickly, and they are losing the environment by increasing the amount of electronic waste. Meanwhile, it seems that this phenomenon is becoming more and more common, which is why I consider it crucial to counteract it at the European level. Mr Durant's report introduces many interesting proposals, such as extending the warranty period or guaranteeing the availability of spare parts, which, in my opinion, can significantly reduce the failure of products. I think that in the future we should additionally try to promote the concept of selling products as services, i.e. selling light, not light bulbs. This approach would, in my opinion, be the best incentive for manufacturers to increase the durability and high quality of their products.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his good work.I am saying here that we would have received much better from this report if, in any case, the PPE Group had not, in fact, opposed the more effective proposals that this report would have needed.The key issues here are repairability, maintenance and access to spare parts.This is a very concrete and important thing.It creates new jobs, saves natural resources, reduces waste and, in particular, creates jobs in small and medium-sized enterprises and micro-enterprises.We definitely had good proposals, even more coercive legislation, more control, more good ideas, but I say it outright that the PPE was against all these things.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the capitalist mode of production is in permanent confrontation with the physical limits of a planet that, being generous in resources, is finite. The constant reduction in the life of products is a manifestation of this confrontation. A system that either grows and accumulates or dies, by definition is not sustainable. In the face of this evidence, there are those who now want to give the system a purifying bath in the cauldron of the wonderful circularity. Debalde, the so-called “circular economy” is not the panacea that some want to make of it. The conversion of waste into resources can be greater or less, but it is never total. In this context, legislative initiatives that impose greater durability of products, that combat programmed obsolescence, that promote the repair market and the existence of extended commercial guarantees, that condition the use of materials depending, for example, on their recyclability, among other measures, they are welcome and necessary.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission would like to thank the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection for this report on a longer lifetime for products and related benefits for consumers and companies. In particular, I would like thank the rapporteur, Mr Durand, for his hard work on this report. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety for their valuable input. I will first speak about the importance of promoting a longer product lifetime. I fully share your views about the importance of longer-lasting products if it affects all of us as European citizens. I am sure that many of us have experienced frustration when domestic appliances have broken down and the price of repair costs as much as – or more than – buying a new product. Also, when IT equipment and software updates are no longer compatible, we can waste a lot of time sorting out these issues. However, we all need to recognise that our products are becoming increasingly sophisticated and more reliant on IT, as well as more efficient. There are trade-offs to be made in keeping a product for 20 years versus having the latest version in terms of costs, energy and material resources. But consumers should have the choice and the possibility to keep a product longer. In addition, value chains in many product markets include both big and small players whose interests may not always necessarily be aligned. Therefore, we need to find a balanced approach in our policies and revelatory interventions. Regarding eco—design and energy labelling actions, in November 2016 the Commission adopted an Eco—design Working Plan for the years 2016—2019, setting out its working priorities and its eco—design and energy labelling framework. The Working Plan has a stronger focus on supporting circular economy objectives. The Commission has committed to explore the possibility of establishing more product—specific and horizontal requirements in areas such as durability, reparability, upgradeability, information and ease of re—use and recycling. The implementation of the Working Plan is currently under way. Regarding European standardisation action, a massive horizontal European standards effort has been mounted since December 2015 by a joint technical committee. This work looks at reparability, upgradeability and durability and is supported by NGOs, Member States and industry. We expect this work to bear fruit by 2019. These standards can then be used for individual product—related legislation and standards. Regarding the role of Member States, your report acknowledges that Member States could also play a role in promoting repairs, for example by putting lower VAT on longer-lasting goods and tax rebates on repair costs. Some Member States – for example, Sweden – are already doing this. We will examine with interest the progress of such schemes. In conclusion, we welcome Mr Durand’s report. We are already acting on some of its suggestions and will reflect in further detail regarding others. We need to work on this together to make changes that make sense for our lifestyles, for businesses and for the planet. So I welcome your support from all relevant committees.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday, 4 July 2017.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - The realization of a circular economy model requires the involvement of political decision makers, citizens and businesses, and implies changes not only in the conception and sale of products and services, but also in the mentality of consumers and entrepreneurial activity. A balance must be found between extending the useful life of products and converting waste into resources, between innovation and consumer demand. Issues such as the durability of the products, the extension of the commercial guarantee, the availability of spare parts, the ease of repairs and the interchangeability of components must be part of the commercial offer of the manufacturer. That of planned obsolescence is a shame that we inherit from the political and business choices of the past, which can only be remedied if we radically change the way we conceive our society. I am in favor of a definition of minimum strength criteria, which include, among other things, robustness, repairability and the ability to evolve, for the various product categories, right from design, to the establishment of an independent system, in able to test and detect obsolescence embedded in products.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. – I endorse this report calling on the Commission to support the implementation of the minimum resistance criteria in order to secure robustness, repairability and upgradability for all product categories.  The initiative follows the results of the survey conducted by Eurobarometer in June 2014. The findings of this survey revealed that 77% of EU citizens prefer to repair their goods instead of buying new ones. Longer lifetime of products is naturally followed by an improvement in functionality of complementary devices and tools, such as batteries or accumulators, that should fully operate for the whole period of usage of the product.  Furthermore, the spare parts should be easily accessible on the market and a clear system of labelling, informing about the durability of the product, should be provided. Apart from the above-mentioned, more durable products will enhance employment in the sectors of repairs, maintenance and rental services and create opportunities for entrepreneurs and SMEs. Moreover, it will provide further security for low-income households, where every investment in a new device or machine represents a significant burden for a family budget.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: in writing. - The report highlights the importance of the circular economy and the economic, social and environmental importance for Europe of converting waste into a valuable resource. In particular, the impact of a longer service life of products on reducing emissions, increasing the security of raw material supplies and increasing the competitiveness of European industry, as well as increasing the production efficiency of companies while reducing costs was emphasized. Undoubtedly, attention should be paid to the problem of faster replacement of goods with new ones; many enterprises, but also households, especially in highly developed countries, replace goods immediately after the end of the warranty, regardless of their further usefulness for use. On the other hand, many consumers have lost confidence in the reliability of the products due to their current low quality. This is especially true for household or high-tech products, which sometimes feel as though they are intentionally designed to have a short life cycle. Therefore, in my opinion, it is necessary to analyze in detail both the issue of assessing the use-by date and to encourage manufacturers to produce machines and devices that are much more durable and of high quality, and additionally promote the creation of repair services in order to reduce waste and unnecessary pollution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - According to the survey, 92% of respondents are convinced that household appliances or advanced technologies are deliberately designed so that they do not last long. Rather, European consumers choose lower-end products from developing countries. This situation is thus paid for by European companies that offer better and more durable products. Longer durability, durability and available repairability of products is therefore a challenge for manufacturers and consumers. It is also a key issue for ensuring sustainable environmental protection. Excessive consumption and short product life increase the cost of disposal and endanger the environment, the atmosphere and ecosystems. That is why I fully support the proposal to take measures that will increase and guarantee the longer life of products and also increase interest in recycling them. At the same time, we will support the interest in creating repair shops. This can estimate up to 296 jobs equivalent to 10,000 tonnes of second-hand products. If we prepare only 1% of such waste for re-use, we will create more than 200,000 jobs.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: written. - The service life of products is important for both the environment and the consumer. That is why it is good to want to extend the life cycle of products. In previous decades, refrigerators, freezers, washing machines, stoves, vacuum cleaners and many other appliances, even in heavy use, often lasted flawlessly for decades. Today, many home appliances contain weak parts that need to be replaced a couple of years after the appliance is put into use. Necessary spare parts and repairs often cost almost as much as new equipment, so repairs are not worth it. In addition, mobile phones, for example, are becoming obsolete. In many products, programmed aging occurs after only a few years. I think we should strive to extend the warranty periods for all machinery and equipment so that companies have an incentive to produce higher quality and longer lasting products. From an environmental point of view, it is unsustainable for the amount of electronic waste to increase while consuming natural resources to produce new products. I am also concerned that, in reality, worthless repair of electronic waste exported to developing countries under the pretext that it could still be corrected. Such waste discharges cause significant environmental problems in recipient countries and endanger the health of many gases when they are released into the respiratory air and groundwater is polluted when toxic chemicals leak into the terrain. I consider the measures set out in the report to be justified, such as easier repairability, dismantling, the availability of spare parts and, for example, the definition of the planned obsolescence of products.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - Increasing the life of the product is a response to the need to preserve raw materials and limit the production of waste, given that, on the one hand, consumers have information on the life of the product and the option to repair it is more attractive, and, on the other hand, manufacturers bring to market products that can be easily repaired and upgraded. Also, a longer product life cycle refers, in a broader context, to changing the way it is produced and consumed today, thus developing economic models in which goods are shared or rented and not necessarily owned. . However, the development of resource-efficient products should not encourage short shelf life or premature disposal of products. In this context, we believe that a balance must be struck between extending the life cycle of products, transforming waste into resources (secondary raw materials), industrial symbiosis, innovation and waste policy, innovation, consumer demand, environmental protection and economic growth in all phases of the product life cycle.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. - Mr President, I am pleased to have a debate on longer product life. This is the right step towards the satisfaction of our citizens and a significant reduction in the waste generated by disposing of not only non-functional appliances. There is a need for the European Commission, Member States and producers to take measures to provide consumers with more durable and repairable high-quality products. Our goal must be to extend the life of our products and combat the built-in obsolescence of goods and software. It is necessary to establish at European level minimum resistance criteria for individual product categories, which producers should take into account at the design stage. We must also not forget to extend the warranty period for products by the duration of their repairs, provided that the repair period is longer than one month. I also appreciate the introduction of a system of voluntary European product labeling, which would focus on durability and repairability. Last but not least, I am in favor of supporting the services of independent repairers in order to prevent intentional damage to products. According to a Eurobarometer survey, up to 77% of consumers in the European Union prefer to try to repair damaged products before buying new ones. Ultimately, however, they are often forced to replace or dispose of the product due to high repair costs and service levels. I will support the report.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Cristian Dan Preda, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on action against human rights, war crimes and crimes against humanity, including genocide (2016/2239 (INI)) (A8-0222/2017).

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: protractor. - Madam President, I would like to start by expressing my satisfaction that today we have reached the final point of this report, which deals with the way in which the European Union has reacted to very serious violations of human rights. man, such as war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide, that is, crimes of atrocities. This is a report that my political group, the European People's Party, has proposed, for three very clear reasons which are clear from reading the text. I will first mention the fact that our Parliament's last resolution on the International Criminal Court (ICC) was six years old. It seemed necessary to me to reaffirm our strong support for this body of justice. The context imposes it, in a way, because we observe, in recent months, that despite the fact that the Court is becoming an increasingly important actor in international justice, it is not immune to questioned. I am thinking, for example, of the recent African Union resolution. This is why this report expresses, in this regrettable context, our unquestionable support for the integrity of the Rome Statute. I also take this opportunity to recall that universal adherence to this statute is the basic condition for the optimal functioning of the Court. In this sense, one of the ideas launched by the report is that the Commission and the European External Action Service assess the actions taken in recent years to encourage the accession of third countries to the ICC and identify best practices in this area. . I also believe that it is time to revisit this 2011 action plan and see where it stands. Also in this context, I would like to welcome the 2015 European Union framework for support for justice in transitional situations. The second point to which I would like to draw attention in this report is that of the prevention. Having the tools at our disposal to try war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide is obviously essential. Preventing is therefore very important. I know that the Commission and the European External Action Service are making real efforts to identify in good time any situation that could degenerate into such crimes, but we must succeed in passing the course of identification in order to move towards action . Of course, we must act jointly with our international partners, but I believe that it is also necessary to take strong positions in our bilateral relations with the countries concerned and to use all the diplomatic and other instruments at our disposal, in the face of possible crimes of this kind. The third axis of my report focuses on the impunity of non-state actors. I am of course focusing on the case of Daesh, because this terrorist organization has committed genocide in Iraq and Syria with the desire to eliminate minorities from the region. It is high time for the Union to make its voice heard on this issue. Two options are possible: either prosecution before the ICC or the establishment of an international criminal tribunal for Iraq and Syria. We need to start thinking seriously about these two possible courses of action, because the wait-and-see attitude is no longer appropriate. I hear the arguments of the detractors, who say that the geopolitical situation will never allow the ICC to be passed, nor the creation of a tribunal. The fact that the ICC has no jurisdiction in Iraq and Syria and that Russia is a permanent member of the UN Security Council should not stop us. What we need is political courage to condemn Daesh and thus allow the victims to rebuild themselves. We must act now because, as I speak to you, Daesh continues to commit crimes against humanity. No state is ready to support Daesh. The blockages are therefore not insurmountable. The Union must play a more prominent role, by putting in place a real strategy to fight Daesh's impunity at the United Nations and with its Member States, knowing that two of them, the United Kingdom and Belgium, are already actively engaged in this battle. The primary objective is to allow society as a whole to turn the page on seeing the executioner condemned, but it must also be remembered that the political, economic and societal reconstruction of Iraq and Syria depends on it. We are no longer talking here only of the moral value of the fight against impunity, but also of its strategic value. First of all, for the countries which are massively affected by Daesh terrorism, but also for us Europeans, who have also suffered from terrorism and who wish to see this region stabilize on a lasting basis. Millions of displaced and persecuted people must be able to return to their homes in safe conditions. This will never be possible if Daesh fighters are still at large. So those are the three thrusts of this report: prevention, support for the international legal order and firm action when it comes to atrocity crimes committed before our eyes. I hope he can contribute to EU policy in this area and I thank the other political groups for their cooperation. Still, I regret that we didn't have an exchange, but it was not accepted. We were only able to get a short introduction. I am glad to see the High Representative in this Chamber.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I am very pleased to have the floor on this point because I consider it to be an extremely important point and I want to congratulate Mr Pred on this report. The question of preventing war conflicts and the clear functioning of the European Union institutions in the event of a potential conflict in the world is a very important matter. That is, if we have a report here that says that we should have an effective procedure for recognizing and resolving such crisis conflicts in a timely manner, then I think that the Commission should really deal with this, and that White Paper, which has already been adopted, further elaborate. I am ready to support this report for another reason, and that is precisely the question of the already mentioned Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. I am also very sorry that the number of countries that have ratified this convention has not increased recently, and we should, as a European Union in the future, work much harder on our partners to take this international body seriously.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the colleagues who worked on this report. The EU must adopt a strong approach on this issue, especially at a time of deteriorating human-rights conditions and increasing conflicts around the world. Of the many pressing issues covered in this report, I would like to highlight the role of women and girls in conflict. Women must play a leading role in conflict prevention and reconciliation and we must never forget the role of victims and survivors in peace building. Their testimonies are hugely important. I meet and work with women survivors of sexual violence in the Western Balkans, especially in Kosovo – women who have suffered abuse through the conflict there and who, years later, are still waiting for recognition, support and justice. Kosovo’s leaders must live up to their commitments and finally provide that support on the ground. As with so many women around the world who have survived war crimes and seen their rights and their bodies violated, these women’s voices must be heard for true peace and justice.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes must be dealt with immediately, there must be severe punishment and, of course, the perpetrators must be prosecuted. Of course, what matters is that we implement a policy that prevents all these crimes, and that is why we must set an example. The perpetrators now see what has happened in the past and are intimidated; and I am clearly referring to the case of Germany's refusal to pay German reparations to Greece. Although there is a decision, since 1946, of the Paris peace agreement, the German side refuses to pay the war reparations, refuses to repay the occupation loan and refuses to compensate the relatives of the victims of the war crimes committed by the Nazi occupation troops in Greece. . You understand, then, that this is unacceptable and must stop and Germany must really pay its debts to Greece. So here are the messages that need to be on these issues.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, we are strongly committed to denouncing and ending impunity for any and all crimes against humanity, war crimes, crimes of aggression, or any other crime. We cannot, however, agree with the cynicism and hypocrisy that transpires from this resolution, where human rights are presented in a manipulated and biased way, defining countries as political targets according to geostrategic and economic interests. The plane is tilted and the targets are the same as always. From outside, unsurprisingly, countries like the United States of America, Israel, Saudi Arabia or even the European Union and several of its Member States that, for a long time, have given examples to the world of the worst atrocities against peoples, including in European soil. The rhetoric surrounding the International Criminal Court undermines what must be sovereign decisions of the peoples and grossly omits its role of bleaching history like the NATO bombings in Yugoslavia, where, ten years after his death, the innocence of Milosevic.

name: Barbara Lochbihler (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President! We regularly receive pictures of terrible war crimes from all over the world. The EU must continue to help prevent such atrocities and hold the perpetrators criminally accountable, including through the support of the International Criminal Court. Suspected war criminals must be investigated in every member state in accordance with the principle of international law. We need to be clear about where war crimes are committed. We did that recently in Parliament for Yemen. But we also have to say who is responsible for it. Unfortunately, there was no majority to clearly and firmly condemn the criminal warfare of the Saudi Arabia-led coalition. With this report, Parliament reiterates its call to you, High Representative Mogherini, for an annual list which specifically lists those suspected of being responsible for violations of international humanitarian law.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, despite the fact that we are in the twenty-first century and one would expect the traces of war to have disappeared, unfortunately even today there are war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocides. In order to lower the morale of the enemy, some warlords use torture and various methods of humiliation and intimidation of the enemy, such as rape of men and women, sexual violence against women, mass murder of religious and ethnic groups, and bombings by bombs. The bad thing is that non-state actors, such as Boko Haram in Nigeria and ISIS in Iraq and Syria, are also involved in this whole situation. In order to control this unacceptable situation, the European Union, as well as the international community, must implement a strategy that will anticipate the possible occurrence of such activities, prevent them and -mostly- punish them immediately and very severely. who are responsible. But for that to happen, everyone must be impartial and punished - not like in Syria, where we condemn the extremism of the regime, but not its opponents.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague Predo for his report, on which I would like to make just a few current remarks. This weekend, the Syrian government rejected a report by the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons about the April attack in Khan Sheikh, in which 80 people died, reporting that the attack was committed by the deadly nerve gas sarin. According to the Syrian Foreign Ministry, this report lacks any credibility and is said to be the product of a sick mind. Russia has also called the report rigged. I would like to strongly condemn this rejection of the professional and impartial report, and I recall that Russia and China have vetoed in the UN Security Council the referral of crimes against humanity committed in the territories of Syria to the International Criminal Court. We know that this gas has been used, and now the attacks should be investigated by a court. I would also like to remind you that it is the religious and ethnic minorities that are most often exposed to crimes against humanity, and we cannot remain silent about them.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, unfortunately, war crimes and crimes against humanity still occur worldwide today, which is why it is an uplifting feeling that this is unthinkable in the European Union and that one of the greatest achievements of European integration is lasting peace among the peoples of Europe. There is perhaps little talk about this aspect, and the people of Europe today cannot even imagine how much destruction war can wreak on the fabric of a society. It is therefore a legitimate expectation on the part of the EU to bring those responsible for crimes against humanity to justice, to bring these people to justice and to ensure that similar incidents do not occur later. Analyzing the lessons of history, however, we can conclude that without the use of military force, war crimes cannot really be prevented, or perhaps those responsible can be punished, but only after a law-making military intervention. If we expect the EU to take action to prevent crimes against humanity, let us add tools to it, otherwise we can formulate these expectations more in relation to NATO.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I am, of course, convinced that war crimes and crimes against humanity, including genocide, deserve debate. I'm sorry it didn't happen. I would like to commend the report presented by my colleague, Mr Preda, and at the same time highlight the very issue of prevention and cooperation that is necessary to address these fundamental issues. I would like to emphasize one legal aspect. In my opinion, it is important to enforce the universal aspect of the non-prescription of these war crimes throughout the world. This means that there really is no so-called "pit" in which criminals committing these war crimes can hide. This is important precisely from the point of view that these criminals will then have no certainty in their lifetime, and our certainty may lie in the fact that the international community will condemn these crimes one day, if not now, then in the next few years.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me first of all thank our colleague Cristian Dan Preda for the work done leading to this report. Let me also mention that, although I have got used to the night sessions of this plenary, I still do not find it completely normal that we are running more than two hours late. I will also be here tomorrow night – diligently – but I still think that this plenary could perhaps work in a more time-efficient manner. Our work to prevent and address human-rights violations is not only – as some of you pointed out – a matter of humanity and values. It is also a matter of interest and strategy for us. Crimes against humanity can spark the next war, propagate conflict or the next refugee crisis; and, in a conflict situation, war crimes make post—conflict reconciliation much harder to achieve, and complicate our work in the post-conflict phase. They destroy the very fabric of society and they spread fear and mistrust, opening wounds that may take decades and a lot of work to heal. For all these reasons our responsibility to protect people and to prevent atrocities is now part of all our main European Union policies. I very much agree with your report’s strong focus on prevention, and in recent weeks we have worked to set up a better early warning system inside the European External Action Service, which also focuses on crimes against humanity. Our military and civilian missions have a very special role to play in this regard because, if we want to prevent human-rights violations, we must also engage with security forces in our partner countries, building their capabilities and training them in respect for human rights. I am also glad to see that your report does not forget to address a very important element of what we are working on here, namely sexual and gender-based violence. Last year alone, the European Union’s aid for the prevention of, and response to, this kind of violence reached almost 3.5 million women, men, girls and boys. Our last package in support of the Syrian refugees strengthens access to protection from gender—based violence for at least 700 000 Syrians, both inside and outside the country. However, beyond prevention, we know that war crimes and crimes against humanity are happening today and that we have a duty to address the consequences. Justice is the only effective and sustainable response to such violence because impunity generates more hatred and often leads to revenge and more suffering. So justice is, for us, the only way towards reconciliation and sustainable peace. To achieve this goal, we are bringing into play a combination of different elements: criminal justice, reparations, truth seeking and institutional reforms. I will mention just a few cases where we are currently at work to prevent impunity and achieve justice. In Syria we are working for the international, impartial and independent mechanism to be fully operational as soon as possible. The European Union is mobilising funds to support this mechanism with up to EUR 1.5 million. I know Member States are playing their part. I am counting on them and also on your support in obtaining even stronger support from the Member State side. In Iraq, as new areas are liberated from Daesh, it is important to assess any war crimes and violations of human rights. We welcome the commitments made by the Federal Government of Iraq and the Kurdistan Regional Government to investigate swiftly all allegations of crimes committed by the Iraqi forces. Beyond Syria and Iraq, last year we led the resolution at the UN Human Rights Council to establish a commission of inquiry in Burundi and we fully support the African group resolution tabled in Geneva last month, which created an international investigation mechanism for the Kasai region in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I very much welcome your acknowledgment of our strong work and support in relation to the International Criminal Court. This is a key element of our strategy. Since 2000, we have committed EUR 37 million in direct support for the International Criminal Court. Last Saturday, we marked 15 years since the Rome Statute entered into force and, for all those 15 years, the European Union has promoted the universal ratification of the Rome Statute.  Last year, as you well remember, we faced a crisis. We kept close contacts with many African states after the Gambia, South Africa and Burundi notified their withdrawal from the Rome Statute and today two of these decisions have been revoked. This is an important achievement, realised in part thanks to the work we have done diplomatically, but we know very well that the work is not over yet. We are currently working on how to improve further the promotion of the universal ratification of the Rome Statute. This is a complex time for the multilateral system at large and for the United Nations and UN system in particular, which has come under attack from many corners. So let me conclude by saying that there cannot be any doubt about the EU’s full support for multilateral global governance based on international law, on human rights and on strong international institutions. The European Union will continue to be a strong, reliable and indispensable partner for the UN and for all who believe that violence must be met with justice and reconciliation. Our work, together with Parliament, will continue in this direction.

Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The fundamental values ​​on which the European Union is based are respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. Advocating for these core values ​​lies at the heart of the great peace project we call the European Union today. The European Union must actively and consistently promote its values ​​not only towards the Member States but also around the world. I support the proposal on measures to protect human rights and prevent the most serious crimes. In its foreign policy action towards third countries, the Union must show stronger support for the human rights enshrined in international law. The problem of impunity for perpetrators of serious crimes, including those who commit crimes on behalf of non-state actors, can only be overcome by the comprehensive jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court. I deplore the pervasive disregard for international humanitarian law and the worrying rates of civilian deaths and attacks on civilian infrastructure in armed conflicts around the world. The EU must work closely with all relevant United Nations bodies with important information to make the prevention of mass crimes as efficient and expeditious as possible. I welcome the use of European instruments to promote the principle of complementarity in order to establish the condemnation of the most serious crimes in international criminal law in national legislation as well.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Hilde Vautmans, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on private security companies (2016/2238 (INI)) (A8-0191 / 2017).

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: Reporter. - Our European citizens are right to ask that we do more to ensure their safety. That is why I think it is now clear that we need to cooperate more, not only between countries, but also between the public and private sectors. You know that the private sector is an expanding sector that is growing in importance every day. More than 100,000 security companies operate worldwide, employing more than 3.5 million citizens, of which 1.5 million in Europe. And that is good. But it is clear that we need a discussion about how to use these firms. Which firms can we deploy, for which tasks, within which legal framework? How can we provide joint training? How can we ensure that the data exchange runs more smoothly? These are all questions that have made it clear to us in committee that there is an urgent need for a legal framework. In fact, Commissioner, we are asking for a directive from the Commission to harmonize the differences between Member States and with standard rules that firms must comply with. In this way, we request, for example, that there is an open list of companies that we as the EU can rely on. That we describe very well what they must meet, which standard requirements they must meet. Because you know that if we bring in firms from within the European Union and they violate human rights, it will also damage our image and that is exactly what we want to prevent here in committee. The report also calls for any contract with the private sector to include detailed requirements on - and it will make sense to you - gun ownership, who works there, what permits are in place and how data exchange is handled. These are things we do ask of the companies that we may entrust with tasks. Mrs Mogherini, our report goes very far in terms of very concrete suggestions and questions to the European Commission. But there is one that is me is particularly important, namely that you should prepare a Green Paper. I know, it is often said, green papers, white papers, so many books ... But I think a green paper is appropriate here. That we initiate clear consultation with all actors within the security data, both public and private, and that we really enter into consultation. I also think this should be done quickly. This is what the citizens of Europe expect. If we have this, Mrs Mogherini, we will be better able to exercise proper control and also see where abuses are occurring. Colleagues, you know that I intervene here very often about defense and in this case I would dare to say: more defense for less money. We know that in Europe there are shrinking defense budgets everywhere, that we have to do it with fewer defense personnel everywhere. And also that the tasks we ask to respect and guarantee our safety require more and more specialization. So we know that if we want to be able to sustain those assignments, we have to work with the private sector. We will be able to increase the safety of our citizens. That is why I hope that you will use this report to come up with that directive and those standards. Then it is also clear what private security firms are allowed to do. "More defense for less money". - Because it should be clear: we are of course not going to use private security firms to take over the tasks of the army. Of course that cannot be the intention. However, we can engage private security firms in field operations to perform certain non-military duties. Then we can also check it very well. Mrs Mogherini, I would very much like us to take this report to heart. I would very much like to thank all colleagues. We have worked very well on this report and I hope that it will be adopted by a broad majority tomorrow.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, of course I recognize that private security agencies and private security services can also play a role in ensuring security.And I also recognize that there is good cooperation with them in many countries, but I do not share the call for new directives on this issue either, because I believe that private security services should enjoy the same rights as any other person who finds himself in a particular situation.a situation where he has the opportunity to take action against the crime committed.But they cannot have more rights than ordinary private citizens.I think that outsourcing services, as the rapporteur said at the end of her speech, is definitely negative in the area of security services, and we should find suitable recommendations for that.With regard to the recommendations that the Commission would adopt, I would like to support this.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, in recent years the private security sector has indeed experienced a strong expansion, also favored by budget cuts in military spending, which have led many European states to outsource security activities to companies private. While we understand the need to contain costs, we cannot agree that the choice to entrust defense services to private companies is determined solely by economic needs. Decisions on defense and security, delicate and complex areas within the competence of public authorities, cannot be based exclusively on logic related to cost containment since, as we all know, security issues involve intelligence activities, investigative activities and strategic planning, and are not limited to merely operational tasks. It is therefore necessary to define a uniform legislative framework at European level, which regulates the activity of private security companies with binding regulatory and monitoring mechanisms to regulate their use also in third countries and with adequate procedures for reporting any irregularities.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, we know that constitutional law and political science determine that the state has a monopoly on the use of legal force, which is why defense and security are entrusted to public authorities. Due to neoliberalism, what we are seeing now is the commission of violence against private companies and in fact it is considered legal. This is an unacceptable phenomenon that cannot continue. We have seen these events happen with private companies that also participated in Iraq and carried out military action. We have seen such companies accused of torture, loss of life, human rights abuses and war crimes. This situation cannot continue and of course I do not agree with setting up a mechanism that will supposedly legitimize the use of violence by private companies. These defense and security issues must be clearly assigned to the public authorities.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). - Mr President, due to the rise of terrorism, the asymmetry of local threats and the manner in which such actions are carried out, the state security forces appear to be unable to cope in a timely and effective manner. The number and range of objectives that exist in the public and private spectrum can be more effectively ensured by the use of organized, equipped and properly trained private security companies. These private companies will be able to cooperate, within a specific framework, with the state security forces at operational and information level. However, it is necessary to formulate the legal basis, clear definition of the rules of establishment and operation of such companies, so that there are no problems of exceeding responsibilities and jurisdiction and especially problems of cooperation and interoperability, which can lead to collateral losses.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I support our colleague's report and I also support the recommendations made. Obviously, the number of companies has increased and we have this statistic of private security companies, we have millions of citizens working here, obviously they will not take over the duties of the army. European citizens increasingly want security and defense. I think it is good to recommend that a Green Paper be drawn up with the involvement of stakeholders and also that there be guidance on joint procurement in the field of employment, use and management of military contractors. I also believe that it is important to develop an effective European model for regulating private security companies. We need to have a European model, not every state has different private security companies. I also argue that there is a need to harmonize legal differences between Member States through a directive. Thanks.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you very much. Let me start by saying that we very much welcome the report on this issue, which can open a new chapter in our awareness about private security companies. Private security companies, as you mentioned, are sometimes essential to safety, including that of European diplomatic and humanitarian operations in the world. On this point the European Union is fully in line with the International Committee of the Red Cross, which means we consider that hiring private security companies is legitimate and can be necessary – for instance, they can have an important role in protecting aid workers or people living in conflict areas – but, of course, these companies are not exempt from the observance of international humanitarian law. In their role as security providers, they must always respect the highest international standards on human rights. The report points out that a legal framework already exists. The private security companies do not operate in a vacuum and the European Union was the first international organisation to sign up to the Montreux Document, promoted by Switzerland and the Red Cross, about obligations and good practices for private security companies. It is now essential that we continue to work for this framework to be expanded and, especially, to be universalised. The UN Human Rights Council is considering drawing up an international framework to regulate, monitor and oversee private military and security companies, and this UN framework could complement and strengthen existing initiatives such as the Montreux Document Forum and International Code of Conduct Association.  I am pleased with the increased recognition of the relevance of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and their implementation. Their value was recognised in the European Union Council conclusion on business and human rights adopted last year. I would like to focus briefly on three points about the work ahead. First, if we want to create a better regulatory framework, progress is in the hands of Member States: in particular they can contribute to changing our current public procurement directives and rules. As for the External Action Service all our potential security contractors have to be signatories of the International Code of Conduct and our delegations closely monitor the implementation of their contractual obligations. Second, the work of security contractors is evolving fast, with a growing role for drones, cyber and civilian military operations. Our systems of safeguards must be continuously updated and we therefore need the cooperation not only of Member States and academics but also of legal experts and NGOs. In particular, we need to assess better which services can be outsourced and which have to remain under the sole responsibility of professional armed forces. My third and final comment is about cooperation between the public and private sectors. Much of the experience of security services in the European public sector in recent years can be of help to the private sector too. Moreover, private security companies are often called on to operate side by side with our military. So it is essential that our institutions continue to engage regularly with the International Code of Conduct Association in order to meet common standards.  Finally, let me conclude by saying that it has been more than 10 years since public opinion began to hear about security contractors. A stronger legal framework for private security companies is in everybody’s interest: it is certainly in the European Union’s interest, so that they can contribute in the right manner to the security of many people, from diplomatic staff to humanitarian workers, around the world.

text: The next item on the agenda is the report by Neoklis Sylikiotis, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on working conditions and precarious employment (2016/2221 (INI)) (A8-0224 / 2017).

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, social poverty and backwardness in employment have forced the European Parliament, in previous reports, to take a stand against policies that lead to the dissolution of the welfare state and against the attack on workers for their rights over the last decade. The report on employment conditions and precarious employment is a continuation of this series of reports. The Committee on Employment of this Parliament has, I believe, stood up to the circumstances and is presenting a balanced report in plenary. On this occasion, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs for the constructive cooperation we have had during the discussions on the report. It is now accepted by all political groups that social protection, protection through collective bargaining and collective bargaining must be accessible to all workers. Today's apparent increase in employment rates hides an increase in precarious forms of employment, such as zero-hour contracts, false self-employment and jobs with involuntary part-time contracts that do not provide decent living and employment rights for workers. A series of surveys, and in particular a survey by the European Parliament's Employment Committee, clearly show that part-time and often part-time workers, who are often required to do so, have grown significantly in the Union over the last 15 years. These contracts may have existed before the financial crisis, however, the inadequate and socially inappropriate solutions provided to combat them exacerbated job insecurity and these are the anti-development policies of austerity and memoranda that led to the disintegration of the social fabric and poverty. sections of the population, mainly employees and retirees. Our goal in this report was to put the concept of employment back on track. Employment must be decent and offer the worker and his family a good and balanced life and all this, of course, in parallel with the social protection of the state to its citizens. As the rapporteur of the report, I think that we, together with the main rapporteurs, have been able to take steps in this direction. We have used the definition of the International Labor Organization for Decent Employment, which defines decent work as full-time and productive employment that ensures the dignity of the worker, a fair income and safety at work, which provides freedom of expression, opinion, organization and participation. in decisions that affect his life and that ensures equal opportunities and equal treatment for all, men and women. We have also condemned abuses in the context of internships or flexible employment contracts. We reminded you that, according to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, every worker is entitled to a maximum working time limit, to daily and weekly rest periods, as well as to an annual paid holiday period. We stressed that this right must apply to all employees without exception. Finally, we called on the Commission and the Member States to ensure effective protection for workers in the context of labor relations, but also a comprehensive political response to reduce and ultimately dismantle precarious employment. Commissioner, there is an urgent need for a change of pace from uncontrolled market and austerity policies. The Union must promote policies that empower workers through social dialogue and the expansion of collective bargaining, ensuring that all workers can exercise their rights. of assembly and collective bargaining freely and without fear.At the same time, the welfare state obviously needs to be strengthened, but policies to create decent jobs through public investment and long-term government strategies are also needed.The Committee also calls on the Member States and the Commission to promote strategies for universal coverage of employees through collective agreements.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, this report responds to the growing number of different forms of employment in the European Union, which it calls precarious. On the contrary, I support the need for some regulation of new forms of work and fundamentally reject the idea that the only decent work is employment for an indefinite period. Time demands that there be flexibility in this area, which is suitable for parents of young children, students or employees of companies that have problems and need employees to reduce their working hours. name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, there is no question that today’s leaders and decision-makers have let down the younger generation. Young people today face continuous precarious employment as a way of life. The internet age has opened up many new opportunities for a dynamic, vibrant economy, but we must not compromise on people’s rights to decent work – and that includes people with disabilities. text: - Mr. President, being employed is better than being unemployed. Let's start with that. Part-time or fixed-term jobs are better than long-term unemployment. This, of course, does not mean that such jobs should be strived for, but also that they should be avoided forever because, as is repeated several times in this report, they are insecure. Politics then tries to present itself as a protector of the people, so it guarantees that it will make these jobs safe. In the long run, a secure job is only one that is commercially viable. Any business that is not commercially viable, and with the help of politics survives, does so at the expense of another who then also becomes unsustainable. The more policies it saves, the more unsustainable they are which then completely sink in times of recession and provoke a chain reaction. text: - Mr President, first of all I want to acknowledge the great work of the rapporteur with this report; And I also consider that it is central to debate about job insecurity, in a context in which in many European countries we are witnessing a change: from the welfare state to the "state of insecurity". Make between forty and eighty beds a day; that 70% of the workers have to take medications to be able to carry out their work activity as a consequence of musculoskeletal and psychosocial diseases; that they charge about two and a half euros per room; that they charge between 20% or 30% less than other jobs of the same professional category, in the same sector, that are not feminized; or the systematic application of fraudulent training and temporary contracts are some examples of how precariousness not only persists, but is growing in a thriving sector that generates more and more profits. But we have more examples of new forms of precariousness. This is the case of the workers of the online platforms - misnamed the "collaborative economy" - such as the Deliveroo workers, who yesterday went on strike in my country. Job insecurity is a social evil that puts the sustainability of many lives at risk, but also of our social State.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, in modern times and in the field of labor, instead of things getting better, they keep getting worse. Therefore, it must be understood that each state has its own economic system and must regulate its own economy, so that it can deal with its problems.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission thanks Mr Sylikiotis for his own-initiative report on working conditions and precarious employment. The report rightly calls for work being transformed through digitalisation and new employment being created as a result of it, to be decent. It also points out the need to guarantee effective protection for workers, regardless of the type and duration of employment relationship, and to address non-standard, atypical and precarious forms of employment, while paying special attention to vulnerable groups. And we hear your call to strengthen social dialogue and promoting the extension of collective bargaining. All these concerns about workers’ rights and opportunities in the 21st century were also raised by different stakeholders last year during the extensive public consultation we organised on establishing a European Pillar of Social Rights. So let me assure you that the Commission is taking action to address those challenges. Let me give you three examples. On 26 April, we launched a social partners’ consultation to collect their views on the possible direction of an EU action to ensure that people in all forms of employment have adequate access to social protection and employment services. We have also initiated a social partners’ consultation on a possible revision of the Written Statement Directive. We want to ensure clarity for workers and employers on their contractual relationship, irrespective of the type of contract. Another important work strand is the European Pillar of Social Rights that we presented on 26 April. Among other things, it aims to promote employment relationships that do not lead to precariousness and to deal with the abusive use of atypical employment contracts. We have opened the discussion on how to better align our social security systems with the new forms of work. We want to ensure that as many people as possible, including the self-employed and gig economy workers, are covered and can build up rights against contributions. The Pillar also recognises the right to fair and equal treatment for workers regarding working conditions and access to social protection and training, regardless of the type and duration of the employment relationship. In addition, the Pillar recognises the right to quality and inclusive education, training and lifelong learning, in order to acquire and maintain skills that enable people to participate fully in society and manage successfully the transition into the labour market. The Commission already recognised the importance of reskilling and upskilling last year. A year ago we launched a New Skills Agenda for Europe, calling on all stakeholders to work together to improve skills in Europe and keep pace with the fast-changing needs of the labour market and society. Last but not least, a word on social dialogue. The Commission is very committed to promote well—functioning social dialogue at all levels. This is also recognised by the Pillar, which encourages the social partners to negotiate and conclude collective agreements in matters relevant to them while respecting their autonomy and the right to collective action. The Commission already supports the capacity-building of social partners in order to develop a broad collective bargaining and effective social dialogue mechanism across the EU. Your report raises awareness of the current challenges, such as the rapid digitalisation or new forms of employment that are blurring the boundaries between dependent employment and self—employment. So we need to act now. Our common goal should be improving the life chances of every European. We need to keep up the momentum for social Europe at all levels. This is why we are aiming at high—level political endorsement of the social pillar by the end of the year. As you know, we have proposed an interinstitutional proclamation of the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament. We count on your support to achieve this goal.
