name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the report by Bernd Lucke, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, entitled "Towards a pan-European framework for covered bonds" (2017/2005 (INI)) (A8-0235 / 2017).

name: Bernd Lucke
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, covered bonds have been a very successful debt instrument for more than 200 years in Europe. They are convenient and efficient for the issuing institutions and they are reliable assets for investors, in particular for financial institutions. This success relies on basically two factors. Factor one is economic: economically the success relies on the existence of high-quality collateral on long-lasting assets which are easily valued and repossessed. The second factor is institutional: institutionally the success relies on the existence of a legal and supervisory framework, such as dual recourse, segregation of cover pools and special public supervision. Given the success of covered bonds, EU law has granted preferential treatment to covered bonds over other assets in various pieces of European legislation, in particular in the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR), in the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive (BRRD) and in the Liquidity Coverage Requirement (LCR) delegated act. This preferential treatment is only justified if the collateral quality is high, so the first factor that I have mentioned is indeed satisfied. However, the problem is that Union law lacks a clear definition of covered bonds. The Undertakings for Collective Investment in Transferable Securities (UCITS) Directive definition is silent on precisely this first factor, on the quality of assets, relying merely on the institutional characteristics of covered bonds. This is not enough to warrant preferential treatment. On the other hand, if we look at the second factor – the institutional environment – this suggests that the institutional environment might be expanded to other types of assets, perhaps more risky and less liquid types of assets and covered pools, such as SME credits, infrastructure projects which are not guaranteed by government, or consumer credits, and possibly to shipping finance.  The European Parliament is suggesting drawing a distinction between three different categories of assets, with the third and final class not called ‘covered bond’ but ‘European secured note’. We would like to distinguish between premium covered bonds and ordinary covered bonds, where the premium covered bonds are those which satisfy the higher criteria on the quality of assets that are specified in the CRR, whereas the ordinary covered bonds are merely UCITS compatible. Parliament is also appealing to national lawmakers to distinguish clearly higher-risk or lower-liquidity assets from those assets which are eligible for UCITS-type covered bonds, leaving SME credits, infrastructure investments and consumer credits to a new instrument which, as I have said, would be called European secured notes. Expanding the institutional environment to these riskier or less liquid classes of assets would be growth-enhancing, we believe, and would serve the objectives of the Capital Markets Union. Moreover, the European Union’s covered bond framework could then be a sort of gold standard for developing covered bond markets world-wide and could open up the EU capital market for issuers in third countries which make use of this efficient debt instrument, provided they have developed a comparable institutional framework. However, we insist that EU legislation be principles-based. One of the principles which should not be compromised is financial stability, and we therefore advise that soft bullet and conditional pass-through structures, which shift issuer risk to investors, may play an important role in preventing fire sales in the event of defaulter resolution, but they should be used only in these cases and only with approval of the supervisory authority. To conclude, what remains to be done, and what this report is silent on, is to remove the market distortions which set CBs at a competitive disadvantage vis-à-vis government bonds. Zero-risk weights for government bonds strongly influence buyers’ market demand by banks in favour of government bonds and are a great impediment in disentangling sovereign debt crisis from banking crisis. It would be preferable to have all risk weights reflect market assessments of risk, and thereby remove a market distortion which disfavours CBs and involves great systemic risk. It would be good if the legislative proposal which the Commission will present to Parliament also addresses this issue.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Bernd Lucke, for presenting this report. We welcome the support the report gives to the harmonisation of covered bonds at EU level. We also welcome the broad consensus among political groups on the way forward. This is encouraging in view of our future work and the upcoming proposal. As announced in the Capital Markets Union mid-term review, the Commission intends to present a legislative proposal on covered bonds in the first quarter of next year. An EU initiative in my view should serve two complementary purposes. First, we should stimulate covered bond markets as a stable and cheap source of funding for credit institutions, and in return, banks should be able to better finance the real economy. Second, we should make sure that our framework is robust enough to justify the preferential prudential treatment granted to it, for instance, in the form of preferential capital risk weights. We welcome the key point made in your report in favour of a principle-based approach, building on the strengths and specificities of existing national frameworks – an approach that would respect the characteristics of national markets that are already working well. The Commission will certainly keep this approach in mind when designing our proposals. In addition, there is a great potential in developing covered bond markets in EU countries that do not have them yet, and also in attracting third-country investors. A robust and widely recognised EU covered bond label would be a major help in this regard. We will be analysing all these elements in the impact assessment that will help us to design the future proposal. We note your interest in building on the success of EU covered bonds in areas where this label cannot be used at this stage. I am referring to the so-called European Secured Notes. The Commission is currently assessing the case for developing this new product. We will decide on possible Commission initiatives on European Secured Notes, following the results of our assessment. However, in the first stage, we will concentrate our action on traditional instruments backed by mortgages or public sector loans. Let me conclude by stressing again the appreciation of the work done by the European Parliament. It is a source of encouragement for our future cooperation in this important field.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Renata Briano, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the role of fisheries tourism in diversifying fisheries (2016/2035 (INI)) (A8-0221 / 2017).

name: Renata Briano
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, small-scale fishermen, especially those in the Mediterranean area, are facing increasing pressures from various factors, including the decline in employment and the lesser attractiveness of the profession, but also climate change and pollution, which have led to a gradual depletion of fish stocks. In Europe, new solutions are being sought and tested, which go towards the diversification of the fishing activity, also developing sectors such as those related to tourism, which in some countries are called fishing tourism and fish tourism. The common fisheries policy already provides for this, but the report was created to give a new impetus to this type of activity. The goal is to create new jobs, promote social inclusion and the revitalization of communities that depend on fishing. Europe's coastal areas attract millions of visitors every year and there has recently been a growing interest in sustainable tourism. Therefore, the diversification of activities will allow not only to help a sector in crisis to recover, but also to help fishermen and tourists to meet and get to know each other through an ancient, difficult and complex profession. Not only that: thanks to this meeting the awareness of responsible consumption can grow, starting from the knowledge of the different species of fish, even of the lesser known ones, which are often less expensive but no less good. To fully benefit from the economic and social potential associated with this sector, it is necessary to act on several fronts: first of all by harmonizing the definition and legal basis of tourism linked to fishing, which sees considerable differences from one Member State to another - for example , in Italy it is considered a professional activity, while in France an occasional activity. It is also necessary to harmonize the European standards on safety, in so you can use the boats used for artisanal fishing for tourist excursions or direct fishing experiences, ensuring the safety of those on board. Finally, it is necessary to encourage investments at national, regional and local level to improve services, from a better Internet connection to the restructuring of plants, passing through the enhancement of local cultures and traditions. The resources made available by the EMFF should be better exploited, and at the same time collaboration between public administrations, FLAGs (i.e. local action groups), tourism experts and stakeholders should be strengthened to promote sustainable growth and to develop innovative products, capable of responding to visitors' expectations. The issue of seasonality could be addressed through information and promotional campaigns capable of offering visitors various activities throughout the year, for example through the organization of events. Tourist activities linked to fishing, in particular fishing tourism and fish tourism, therefore represent a real form of integration and diversification of the primary activity in many European regions, and are economically advantageous for fishermen and environmentally sustainable. Unfortunately, however, they are still too little known by the general public and too little valued by the institutions. For this there is a need for a common and shared effort that involves all stakeholders and that allows coastal communities, fishermen and tourists to fully benefit from the great opportunities this sector has to offer. I take this opportunity to thank all my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, for their help and interest in the work we have done together.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I do not want to question the importance of this issue, even in relation to the petitioner's jurisdiction.I understand that fishing tourism can really bring new jobs.I do not even question the social cohesion that this issue can really bring.Undoubtedly, it also has the dimension of cooperation between the states: Croatia, Italy, Slovenia, this is the Adriatic region.But what I am really questioning is the question of the need to define a legal basis for this activity, that is, for fishing tourism.I think this is something that does not need to define a legal basis.We should focus on sustainability.So that the level of depletion of the resources of our seas and coastal waters is not as extreme and as high as it is today.We should focus on that, but if we need to define a legal basis, I clearly doubt that.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Renata Briano, on the initiative of this report and on its final content. Income diversification is essential for fishing in Europe. On the one hand, many springs are depleted and, on the other, fishermen are struggling to recover their income. Sustainable solutions must be found and this may be one of them. Within strict security conditions, professional fishing vessels craft from the Azores - the region where I come from - can operate with tourists on board. At this moment, there is already a combination of efforts between the fishing industry and the restoration, which allows the visitor to assist and assist in the capture and then learn how to prepare the fish, according to the tradition of this outermost region. This is a process coordinated by the Association of Women in Azorean fishing. I believe that the Azorean example can and should serve as a model for other areas of island and continental Europe.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank Mrs Briano for the work she has done and tell her that I agree to diversify the income of the fishing areas, but that we must not forget that her main activity is fishing. Its products, the trades, the traditions and the culture that derive from it are the basis for building attractive diversification activities. I am going to abstain from voting because this report focuses more on suggesting the possibilities that tourism opens up than on ensuring that local communities are the ones who enjoy the supplementary income from new activities to make their activity sustainable. I miss more references to the protection of fishing and its professionals and their role in the design, entrepreneurship and commercialization of the offer of new goods and services. Only in this way will we guarantee that it is based on authenticity - the key to its success - and we will ensure that benefits, much more than jobs in the hospitality sector, remain in these areas so pressured by factors such as pollution, seasonality, reduction of fishing quotas or the limit of the number of species they can catch.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, we understand that tourism linked to fishing, if carried out responsibly, can be a complement to the fishing sector and contribute to the enhancement of the culture of fishery products. But I want to make it very clear that tourist activities cannot, under any circumstances, replace or have negative impacts on the various types of fishing. Fishing is, above all, a fundamental economic activity in countries such as Galicia and other coastal areas in Europe. Fishermen and women want to live off their work, they do not want to become tourist guides. We must keep in mind that not all areas have the same possibilities to attract fishing tourism and that these types of projects, if not developed in a responsible manner, can be quickly exhausted and be extremely seasonal. For this reason, we ask for a lot of prudence before any type of tax incentive for maritime tourism. I also think that the EU should support, first of all, that fishing is environmentally and economically sustainable and should give priority to the consumption of local fishery products.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the cell door slammed shut behind him. He remained leaning against the bolted metal door for a few seconds before pacing across the cell – 10 paces in all. He still couldn’t really believe it. What had the judge said? ‘You must pay for your criminal actions: take him down’. What had he done? He had gone fishing. Just a bit of fun. The catch was unimportant. What was the technical term? ‘Common fisheries policy prohibited recreational angling catch’. How was he to know that he was only allowed to catch two bass, that the third – he hadn’t asked it to bite, it just had, and it made him a criminal. How did you get banged up for going fishing? The world was truly absurd. This could be a short story by Kafka; in its implications, this report is both frightening and absurd. You are thinking of the stuff of dystopian nightmares and not fit for the real world and a tyranny to ordinary people and ordinary fishermen throughout Europe.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, tourism and fishing for citizens living in the Croatian Adriatic, in those areas, especially on islands, where fish are traditionally fished, is something we are considering here today, and we can say that the proposal of this report is in some way a win win.combination.A synergy between what tourism creates today, as a relatively new industry, and fisheries as a traditional industry in Croatia.I would like to point out the fact that in this way many problems that fishing also faces can be solved, many families can dedicate themselves to the so-calledtourist fishing and can create for themselves new income and new opportunities.Of course, fishing as a whole cannot be bypassed in this way, but something can certainly be done for the benefit of those people who have fewer and fewer fishing opportunities.Finally, I call on us not to forget about river fishing and the harmonization of European Union regulations.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the deep crisis in which the fisheries sector is experiencing in several countries and regions, and in particular the small-scale fishing segment, has very identifiable concrete causes. Inseparable causes of the failure of the European Union's Common Fisheries Policy in its various dimensions: it failed to ensure a decent income for fishermen, it failed to contribute to the socio-economic development of coastal regions, it failed to ensure the supply of fish to populations within the framework of a good conservation of resources. It is in the context of this resounding failure that many of the theories of diversification emerge, which, moreover, have parallels in other sectors such as agriculture. Without calling into question positive aspects that may result from activities that, alongside fishing, are complementary (and not alternatively) carried out by fishermen, as is the case with tourism, it is important to underline that the primary objective and function of the fisherman is to fish. So that they can continue to do so for many years, what we need is, first of all, a change in policies.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome Parliament’s own-initiative report on the role of fisheries-related tourism in the diversification of fisheries. As Ms Briano rightly pointed out in the report, supporting small-scale coastal fisheries, and promoting diversification within and outside commercial fisheries towards tourism activities, in particular at the local level, is important for the socio-economic fabric of coastal areas and helps to improve the quality of life of fishermen and their families. Thanks to the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, which is the structural support tool for the common fisheries policy for the period 2014-2020, Member States can implement several of the measures that are proposed in the report. Concerning diversification within commercial fisheries, these measures range from training of fishermen, promoting networking and exchange of experiences and best practices to diversification and new forms of income for fishermen. We estimate that these measures amount to close to EUR 65 million of European Maritime and Fisheries Fund resources under shared management. As regards the specific support to small-scale coastal fishing, let me underline the fact that the fund permits higher aid intensity rates of up to 80% for all operations related to small-scale coastal fishing. Some examples of the latter are: support for young fishermen in starting out, health and safety, diversification, partnerships between scientists and fishermen, training, life-long learning, marketing and processing and innovation. For activities outside commercial fisheries, fishermen can apply for funding under community-led local development, in the framework of a local development strategy. Approximately 10%, or around EUR 519 million of our fund, is devoted to community-led local development. Under the EMFF, 73% of all local development strategies funded include tourism as an important part of their strategy. Therefore, in the current period, the Commission estimates that approximately three quarters of all expected 350 fisheries local action groups will have included tourism as one of their main areas of action in their local development strategies. Thus, tourism-related activities feature prominently. And this should be surprise. Tourism employs over 3.2 million people and generates a total of EUR 183 billion in gross value added. It represents over one third of the maritime economy. An important part of that is marine recreational fisheries, which are becoming increasingly important for many coastal communities that rely on tourism. Our 2014 coastal and maritime tourism strategy, which you have also mentioned, considers recreational fishing as one of the options for diversifying the tourism offer and for helping address the issue of seasonality. We are supporting this diversification, for instance we have three ongoing projects funded under the EMFF that are linked to underwater cultural heritage, which is also in line with the 2018 European Year of Cultural Heritage. Thematic itineraries along nautical routes have been very successful, and we are currently selecting new projects for funding. In March this year, we presented the nautical tourism staff working document, which analyses a number of actions to be undertaken in the field of nautical tourism. These range from support for the qualifications of professional yacht skippers and recreational boating, to waste prevention and the management of marine litter. You have highlighted the importance of sustainability and preservation of resources. 2017 is the UN Year of Sustainable Tourism for Development. The Commission has been working towards promoting sustainable tourism for many years, through initiatives such as the European destinations of excellence, a Commission initiative which promotes sustainable tourism destination models, dealing with seasonality and rebalancing the tourism flows towards non-traditional destinations.  Sustainable tourism also has an important focus in some sea-basin strategies, such as the European strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian macro-region, where sustainable tourism is one of the central pillars. Also in the context of marine protected areas we work with member states to support the creation and extension of existing marine protection areas, and to ensure that tourism activities in marine protection areas are managed in a sustainable manner, and are preferably distributed in a balanced way throughout the year, avoiding summer peaks.  In conclusion, we welcome this report and its emphasis on promoting smart, sustainable and inclusive tourism, also at the local level, by pulling together the resources, contact persons and actions of all the relevant services. We hope that by doing so, we will be able to preserve both our traditional fishing activities and our marine resources, while ensuring the well-being of people living in those fishery areas.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 4 July 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: signed up. - In recent years, a large proportion of traditional fishing communities throughout the European Union are under increasing pressure due to several negative factors, such as overfishing and declining fish stocks, climate change, pollution, declining population and, not lastly, the declining attractiveness of the fishing profession. Fishermen in the Danube Delta are in this situation. Poor living conditions make it difficult for generations to change, with young people preferring to migrate to cities where living is easier. The population is aging, forced to live in harsh living conditions, and fishing income is very low. Unfortunately, more and more traditional fishing communities in Europe can no longer depend solely on traditional fishing. In order for them to recover and remain viable, the Union needs to promote their involvement in related activities such as tourism. I therefore call on the Commission to actively promote and support investments aimed at diversifying fisheries activities in terms of marketing and processing of local fishery products, as well as to stimulate the development of local fish distribution channels.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to inform Parliament that during the recent government crisis in Romania, almost the entire Romanian political elite and leading press have become anti-chauvinist anti-Hungarian, which is extremely dangerous for the stability of Romanian democracy and inter-ethnic relations. With this, the aim may have been to postpone the resolution of the political crisis, but in the meantime the Romanian public was able to be attuned against the 1.3 million indigenous Hungarian minority. In addition to the extreme outbursts of opposition party presidents, journalists carried out a disinformation campaign on various news channels, painting a completely false image of Hungarians living in the country, otherwise making unconstitutional legitimate and legitimate requests to which the country committed itself by ratifying international agreements. The rejection of dialogue in resolving the majority-minority relationship is never good, as the peoples of Europe have experienced. We hope that in the case of Romania, the majority will be willing to sit at a negotiating table, as it will always find a partner in the minority, and thus a majority-minority agreement, a new beginning in Romanian-Hungarian relations.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am sure all of you heard about Charlie Gard, a 10-month-old boy in the UK suffering from a rare genetic disease. His doctors concluded that he is no longer entitled to be in this world. Both the domestic courts as well as the European Court of Human Rights approved to discontinue his life-supporting treatment, including nutrition and hydration, and ruled in favour of ending Charlie’s life in absolute contradiction to his parents’ will to seek experimental treatment in the USA. How is it possible that even today, when we designate our era as one which respects the most fundamental values of life and human dignity, the United Kingdom does not act in the best interests of its citizens? Imposition of switching off the life-supporting treatment is nothing else than euthanasia. Together with all those of you who demonstrated your support, I strongly condemn this shameful conduct that undermines values of our civilised society’s right to life and human dignity.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, tonight I would like to talk about human rights, human rights in a European Union member state. What is it about: for twenty years, in my country, in Romania, there has been a major investment by some Turkish citizens in educational institutions. The investment is exemplary and over three thousand children study in this institution. Unfortunately, in recent years, Turkey, through its state institutions, but even through the Turkish Embassy in Romania, is putting pressure on investors, on teachers of Turkish origin who work in these institutions, on their families. Arrests have even been made, scams are being carried out, passports are being taken away, passports are not being extended. Basically, the educational institution, which has been operating for twenty years, is disrupted, but what is more dangerous is that these citizens, who live and have made an investment in a European state, are not protected. My question is: can the Commission do anything? Can we do something? We are in agreement with Turkey, we cannot leave our citizens unprotected.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, British citizens living in EU countries and EU citizens living in the UK have been suffering acute anxiety since last year’s referendum in the UK. EU citizenship rights are under serious threat, despite being enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. Theresa May’s offer to give residency to some EU nationals if they jump through hoops and pay for the privilege is neither fair nor generous. Indeed, it is an insult to people who have lived and worked in the UK for years. And what of the million or so who will not meet the five-year residency rule, many of whom are Eastern European and Roma, told to go home by emboldened racists? The Tory Government, under Theresa May’s shambolic leadership, is responsible for dividing our communities and whipping up xenophobia. A year on from the referendum and we are still no closer to a clear answer on the future of citizens living on both sides of the Channel. This is simply unacceptable.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, the arbitration procedure between Croatia and Slovenia, contaminated by a major scandal, has come to an end. After Slovenian member of the Sekolec Arbitration Court and Slovenian MP Drenik were caught exchanging confidential information, Croatia - which entered the arbitration in good faith - left it by a unanimous decision of Parliament. The procedure that was supposed to resolve the dispute thus brought even more controversy into the relations between the two countries and further poisoned the story about the demarcation. And now what? Neighbors and partners must sit down and renegotiate a new solution. I hereby appeal to the Commission and other Member States to take into account the fact that one member justifiably left the arbitration and does not recognize the decision of the court which, with Croatia's withdrawal from the proceedings, lost all legitimacy in this case. Pressure on Croatia to recognize such arbitration will mean directing one member against another and subtly endorsing non-transparency and corruption in international institutions. It would be a big step in the wrong direction for the European Union!

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, the decision of the arbitral tribunal on the border line between Croatia and Slovenia is non-binding for Croatia because Croatia came out of this arbitration process, which of course, as we know, was very contaminated by the Slovenian side. However, I also start from the fact that the decision made by that arbitral tribunal can be a good starting point for seeking a final solution between two partners, between two friendly countries. So, I think the bilateral talks that are expected and I call on the Prime Ministers to really find a final solution as soon as possible so that the people living along the border, together with me because I live along that border, are really calm and peaceful because today they are very worried about everything. what is happening and things, I hope, will not get out of control. That is why I welcome the responsible reactions of the leaders of Slovenia and Croatia and I welcome their intention to find a final solution quickly. I think this is the only way and in that context I believe that they will have the support of all of us because peace and stability in the region is primarily what the citizens are interested in.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, at the end of April a proposal was made for an interinstitutional proclamation on the European pillar of social rights. There are 20 concrete proposals that appear as an authentic manual of exploration and leveling, below, of the labor and social rights. They promote the deepening of exploitation and precariousness through flexibility, attack the right to social protection and public and universal social security, align the retirement age with life expectancy, defend the precariousness and the submission of social and labor rights to desideratos of the bosses, the big capital and the interests of the directory and the powers of the European Union. Any reference to public service policies such as education or health is eliminated, they take on a mercantilist view of rights whether in social protection, health, education, water, sanitation, energy, transport, among others. Whoever wants them to pay them. The exploration manual that urgently needs to be rejected and with it the policies and constraints of the European Union that promote poverty, inequality and the asphyxiation of sovereign peoples and countries.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr. president. It is not the first time in this Chamber that I denounce the scandal of the Castor project, between Catalonia and the Valencian Country, which sought to inject natural gas into an old oil field and which caused more than 500 seismic movements. When that absolutely nefarious project was paralyzed, the Spanish State promised to pay more than 1.3 billion euros as compensation to the company. More than two years ago - April 2015 - the European Parliament regretted the actions of the European Investment Bank and the European Commission, which it required to take measures to prevent Spanish citizens from having to assume that compensation. The European Commission has not yet responded to our demands. The Spanish State is proceeding with covert aid, with the excuse of compensation. This is an unacceptable scandal and the Commission is jointly responsible for it by doing nothing. So I denounce it again, again, again.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Mr President, a tribute was paid on Saturday 1 July, at the European Parliament in Strasbourg, to the former German Chancellor Helmut Kohl.In my view, this tribute is problematic for two reasons.First, because Helmut Kohl was first and foremost in the service of Germany.He reunified his country and created the euro on the model of the mark.If the European Union is now so dominated by Germany, it is to him that it owes it.You will understand that, as a Frenchman, I do not congratulate myself on that.On the other hand, the tribute was also problematic because it was paid not by MEPs, but by personalities, most of them not even elected, who came to occupy the MEPs' benches.The Union had already invented democracy without a people; on July 1 it invented Parliament without parliamentarians.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). - Mr. President, in Greece, with a law-mockery of the SYRIZA-ANEL government, thousands of contractors in the municipalities will be fired and very few will be made permanent. You see, the privatization of cleaning and recycling is being methodized, for the profits of the entrepreneurs who will undertake, with new heavy excavations for the citizens. Short-term crumbling and multi-month unemployment as growth incentives are the best practice of the European Union, bourgeois governments and local authorities, liberal social democrats and all sorts of opportunists who called for a European directive not to renew contracts, to recycle not to acquire rights. The multi-day strike of contract workers in Greece, which was met with threats, repression and guided social automation by all parties that are silent today about the worker who died and another who is rejoicing over the intensification of work in the heat, showed that stable permanent work for all - a direct demand for popular survival and mobilization of the working class - is a nail in the soul of the system. That is why the struggle must be linked to its own overthrow.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to turn our attention to a subject that really deserves our great attention, and that is the issue of drought. Many Member States, as well as individual regions, are currently facing a drought that is reaching catastrophic proportions, and the fact that Europe is drying up is an indisputable fact. I think it is important to look for new impulses in water management within the Czech Republic, which is also affected, especially the Moravian regions. We need sustainable water management and we need to be inspired abroad, where this basic resource is already being used very economically. It is essential that we behave sparingly, both individually and, of course, in the treatment of, say, industrial, water, but at the same time I would like our cohesion policy to include some impetus for such disadvantaged regions. I think they need our help and these impulses are absolutely necessary.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, dear fellow citizens, on 2 March this year, we voted by a large majority in a resolution obliging the Commission to comply with European legislation on the issue of visa reciprocity. Four months later, we are back where we were fourteen years ago - a strategic inaction on the part of the European Commission. For several months, the US president has shown that he does not respect international commitments. The European Commission has apparently decided to tolerate just this model. I find the decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs, supported by the political groups of the ENP, ALDE and the Conservatives, which voted against the will of the majority of MEPs and against the interests of the citizens of Bulgaria, Romania, Poland, Cyprus and Croatia, extremely disappointing. Mr Tajani, you said in your campaign speech that the European Parliament needs a President who works for everyone. Show that you can work for these 70 million Europeans and take the necessary steps to stop discrimination against them.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, the ink of the harsh second evaluation did not even dry up and the troika began to demand new measures in view of the forthcoming third evaluation. Thus, after the imposition of the third and fourth memorandum, after the cutting of pensions, after the imposition of constant harsh austerity until 2060, after the launch of the sale of public property and the country's wealth-producing resources for 99 years, through the occupation fund, The troika and Mr Moscovici have also announced new measures against retirees since September. And all this while the troika and the lenders do not pay at least 30% of the loan funds of the third loan package of 86 billion. According to a Commission document, € 24.7 billion will be left over after the end of the third memorandum. So why does the Greek government not ask for the reduction of the memorandum measures by 30%, since the lenders will give only 70% of the loan? However, the Greek people are not going to tolerate the troika and its barbarians and soon with their struggle they will give them the message that there is another way.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Ladies and gentlemen,The decision of the European Commission to initiate legal steps against Poland and Hungary is either a deliberate division of European countries or a complete failure to withdraw from the wrong immigration policy.Both are the worst evidence of the current direction and methods of operation of the European Commission.The case has one more aspect.In fact, Poland and Hungary are under attack because they openly and honestly reject policies that the vast majority of European countries reject in practice.This shows that the European Commission is really only about perpetuating the ideological lie about the approval of the public opinion of the peoples of Europe for the eggs of immigration policy.Of course, nothing permanent can be built on a lie.The more and the sooner people in Europe realize this simple truth, the more opportunities we will have for fruitful and authentic cooperation between our peoples.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the Commission has developed a connectivity plan for the Western Balkans, and an important component of that connectivity is energy connectivity with the aim of market integration in order to reduce electricity supply requirements and obtain cheaper electricity.An important part of this energy connection is cooperation within the energy community in which the countries of the Western Balkans define joint projects and agree on the adoption and application of common standards in electricity generation and supply.The countries of the Western Balkans plan to build eight coal-fired power plants that do not meet the high standards of the European Union, primarily in terms of environmental protection and air quality.I therefore call on the Commission, in the context of the Connectivity and Energy Community Plan, to help these countries adopt the highest environmental standards in the construction of thermal power plants.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, a few days ago the Bank of Spain considered 60 600 million lost in the bank rescue. Soon after, another 1,000 were lost in the Mare Nostrum-Bankia merger. With this money, it would not have been necessary to resort to the reserve fund to pay pensions, or to close hospitals and schools, or to reduce social protection. And it could go on. And that, without counting the interest or indirect aid, such as the tax credits that Banco Santander will receive for the purchase of Popular, while thousands of small savers lose all their capital in an entity declared solvent, an enigma and a shame that the Government the Spanish State and the ECB will have to explain us. The bank bailout is a bottomless pit that leaves us with a concentrated, fragile financial system far removed from the real economy. The path of growth requires rescuing workers, pensioners, families, victims of a predatory and unsustainable financial system.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, we continue to advance towards the self-determination referendum that will take place in Catalonia on October 1, a referendum that between 70% and 80% of Catalans support. And, as we move forward, the Spanish Government, unable to politically manage such a broad and legitimate demand, continues to be locked in its world of disqualifications and threats. These days it has been up to the mayors. We are threatened with acting against our supposed - if we have it - audacity to collaborate so that our fellow citizens can vote with full democratic normality. Well, the vast majority of mayors in Catalonia will be up to par, we will always be on the side of democracy, the ballot box and the people. When a State threatens political representatives who want to put ballot boxes, this State has a serious problem. And when the state that threatens those of us who want to put ballot boxes is a member state of the European Union, then it is the entire Union that has a problem.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, it is exactly 25 years since the de facto disintegration of Czechoslovakia began with the non-election of Václav Havel as president, part of the deputies elected in Slovakia, who demanded the division of the federation and an independent Slovakia. Vaclav Havel understood the will of the Slovak nation and resigned. After the establishment of the independent Czech Republic, he was elected the first Czech president in January 1993. His act contributed to the division of Czechoslovakia in a peaceful way in the form of an agreement, which some countries consider exemplary. I am talking about this because this Wednesday, 5 July, we will be opening a new building here in Strasbourg, which will bear the name of Václav Havel. It will be the seat of the European Ombudsman and will certainly suit Václav Havel, because he was, and symbolically, will remain the defender of citizens' rights. Strasbourg is a symbolic city for both the French and the Germans. This connection of the two banks symbolizes the price of peace. At that moment, we Czechs can be proud that the seat of the European Ombudsman will bear the name of Václav Havel in this city.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, tonight I am pointing out the unjustified request for a two-month postponement of the application of the delegated act which enables Croatian producers of Teran wines to be placed on the European market. Teran wine is produced in Slovenia from the Refošk variety, and in Croatia from the Teran variety. Due to its earlier accession to the Union, Slovenia was able to protect the geographical origin of its wine earlier, and Croatian producers suffered significant damage due to the impossibility of placing their product on the European market. On May 19, the European Commission regulated this issue by a delegated act, so that in addition to the name Teran, the appendix Croatian Istria was printed. However, a request for a postponement of its application was submitted a few days before the entry into force of the act. The Agriculture Committee will vote on this next week. I urge that the unfounded request to postpone the application of the delegated act on Teran be rejected. Croatian winemakers have been waiting 4 years too long. Product names in many cases cross national borders, which is the best evidence of the product’s common past and need for collaboration. I expect that all producers of Teran will be able to place products whose quality and geographical origin, as well as legal arguments for protection are absolutely unquestionable.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, when the Berlin Wall fell I was sitting in my father’s little Fiat 750 in Sarajevo, hoping to be in Berlin and see what freedom looked like. I was already this long, so I had to take the first seat out of the car in order to fit in that little car. But it didn’t help. The car was produced in a socialist fabric in the former Yugoslavia, so we didn’t make it. Freedom was not yet for us. For us, freedom will come later, after years of blood, tears and tragic war. The other Europeans experienced, in the same time, the spread of liberal and democratic values. I am deeply convinced that one of the reasons for that is the wise statesmen who could deal with such tremendous challenges. One of them was Helmut Kohl. He believed in building a new Europe – united, enlarged and free. This is exactly how we should bid farewell to him – by finishing that project. Believing in the power of this legacy, believing that Europe one day will be enlarged, united and peaceful and that even my two friends who were on that unsuccessful trip with me will one day join us.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: - In Galicia, last month, the police carried out extremely tough police charges against people who were demonstrating against the eviction of the Centro Social Escárnio and Maldizer, which caused dozens of identified wounded people, some of whom were detained the following day.Now, the Directorate-General for Police has announced that it will process some 400 sanctions against 116 people.The Professional College of Journalists of Galicia denounced and condemned the police impediments to cover this demonstration.The Government Delegate in Galicia stated, in a radio interview, that the Spanish Government controls and persecutes people who regularly attend demonstrations.All of this constitutes very serious violations of the right to freedom of expression and expression.This Parliament has often condemned situations like these when they happen in third countries.We must set an example and act strongly when this happens in a Member State.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I wanted to draw attention to one thing that is related to the European Commission's current policy. As we all know, on 13 June, the European Commission opened proceedings against three countries, the Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary, on the grounds that these countries refused to implement mandatory quotas and accept refugees. I would very much like the European Commission, when it has chosen such a tough solution, to also perceive what this Commission decision evokes among the people of Central Europe. What are the implications of how it strengthens anti-European sentiment and anti-European thinking? Parliamentary elections will take place in the Czech Republic in the autumn of October, and I am - unfortunately, I emphasize this - convinced that this radical path of the European Commission will lead to the strengthening of populist and anti-European forces in Czech politics and the Czech Parliament. And that is something I am not happy about and do not want. So, perhaps, the Commission should be more political and think about whether the solutions chosen will really lead to the desired goal, and that is to strengthen the European Union. In this way, we strengthen only Russia and Europe's enemies.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Italy thousands of people will gather in the next few hours in front of the Italian parliament to demonstrate against the ratification of the CETA, approved by this House in February with 408 votes in favor, 33 abstentions and 250 votes against, including which my. First of all, these are farmers, worried because this agreement represents the first pass for imitations of better known and less protected Italian gastronomic products. They are consumers and environmentalists, alarmed by the lowering of food safety standards and the spread of GMO production. They are workers and small entrepreneurs, afraid of further downward competition, which they must pay dearly through further social dumping. But the protests are not only Italian: in many Member States there are demonstrations of this kind. The Commission's commitment to follow the evolution of the situation with the utmost attention is central, blocking all attempts to violate the rules that may contribute to damage our products, employment, the environment and health.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, for patients with neoplasms, the inclusion in a clinical trial of a new method of treatment or experimental technology may mean the chance of an improvement in the quality of life, a regression of the disease stage or even the difference between life. and death. Unfortunately, there are also cases where these opportunities are not distributed equitably among the citizens of the European Union, although one of the fundamental concerns of the European Parliament is to give equal rights to all European citizens, regardless of which Member State they belong to. In the case of the APOLLO clinical trial, for patients suffering from multiple myeloma, a study supported by the Janssen company, no Romanian patient has yet been included in this trial. Although Romania was warmly recommended by the study coordinator, Professor Dimopoulus of the University of Medicine in Athens, and although Romania meets all the conditions to be included in this trial, in the Balkans, only Greece, Turkey and Serbia were accepted for this study. Asked, the representatives of the Janssen company motivated the refusal based on administrative problems, unacceptable when the lives of some people are in the middle. I appeal in this way to a reconsideration of this decision and to the re-evaluation of Romania in order to be included in the future stages of the APOLLO study.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the discussion on this item on the agenda.
